This is a network transformation (a measurement primitive), not a state\u2010generation target, and it directly fuses \u201clasing behavior\u201d (gain) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single_emitters).  \nStep 2: Novelty: No existing Pytheus experiment builds a Bell\u2010state analyzer on matter qubits using heralded gain elements. Feasibility: it uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for both Bell\u2010resources and gain blocks), beam splitters, phase\u2010shifters, and post\u2010selected detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s static linear\u2010optics framework.  \nStep 3: This idea is novel because it proposes overcoming a fundamental LOQC bound (50% Bell\u2010measurement success) by embedding heralded PDC amplifiers into the measurement network\u2014a qualitative change in measurement power, not just a success\u2010rate tweak.  \nStep 4: It is feasible in Pytheus since all components (single_emitters, PDC sources, beam splitters, detectors) are supported, no cavities or fast feedback are needed, and we focus purely on network design for a Bell\u2010measurement transformation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer on two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a novel network transformation:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have two abstract qubits encoded in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081 (nodes 0 and 1). Our goal is a linear\u2010optical circuit that can unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of these qubits with success probability >50%, by incorporating two additional PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers in the ancilla arms of the Bell analyzer.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n                             \u251c\u2500\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n             \u2191                  \n         Source S\u2090 (Bell resource)  \n  \n  And symmetrically a second Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u2082 fed by Source S_b and Gain block G\u2082, interleaved by a small multiport interferometer that mixes the four modes.\n\n\u2022 S\u2090,S_b are two standard PDC pair sources generating the entangled ancilla photons for the two halves of the Bell analyzer.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) placed in one arm of each Bell measurement. Their pump amplitudes are tuned to amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, mimicking lasing.  \n\u2022 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters implements the two partial Bell measurements (\ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082) and then recombines/splits modes to route each possible Bell input to a unique four-click detector pattern.  \n\u2022 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors monitor the outputs. Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # mapping each Bell basis input (00\u00b111,01\u00b110) to a unique detector pattern  \n    \"0000\",  # corresponds to |\u03a6\u207a>  \n    \"0011\",  # |\u03a6\u207b>  \n    \"1100\",  # |\u03a8\u207a>  \n    \"1111\"   # |\u03a8\u207b>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # the two matter\u2010qubit inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],       # allow all PDC\u2013detector paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey Features & Generalizations:  \n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1] hold the qubit inputs in abstract modes.  \n\u2022 PDC sources S\u2090,S_b supply the ancilla photons for the standard Bell measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded PDC gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082 inserted into each Bell analyzer ancilla arm simulate \u201clasing behavior,\u201d boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude and thus the measurement\u2019s success rate.  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer routes each Bell state to a distinct four-click pattern\u2014realizing unambiguous discrimination.  \n\u2022 By varying G\u2081/G\u2082 pump strengths, one explores the transition from 50%\u2010limit to near-unit success, directly illustrating how gain alters network measurement capabilities.  \n\u2022 This primitive can be extended to multi-qubit Bell analyzers, gain-boosted parity checks, and repeater nodes with tunable fidelity\u2013efficiency trade\u2010offs, opening a new class of quantum\u2010network elements at the intersection of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design an \u201camplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate\u201d between two single\u2010photon emitters, combining lasing\u2010style gain (via extra PDC sources) and strong light\u2013matter coupling (abstract single_emitters) in a heralded teleportation network.\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to realize a post\u2010selected SWAP gate on two emitter\u2010qubits E_A and E_B by teleporting E_A\u2192E_B and E_B\u2192E_A simultaneously, but boosted by \u201cgain\u201d PDC sources that amplify the Bell\u2010measurement success probability (mimicking lasing behavior).  \n\n1) Single\u2010photon emitters [0] and [1] prepare the two arbitrary input qubits (strong light\u2013matter coupling nodes).  \n2) Two PDC sources (S1, S2) generate the Bell pairs needed for teleportation.  \n3) Two additional PDC sources (G1, G2) act as heralded gain blocks: each is placed in one arm of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer to probabilistically amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, thereby increasing the teleportation success amplitude.  \n4) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the Bell\u2010measurement on the four photonic modes (two from emitters + two from S1,S2), interleaved with gain blocks G1,G2.  \n5) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancillary modes; successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n the middle of each Bell circuit; G1,G2 (gain PDCs) are inserted in the two ancilla arms.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Amplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP This falls short of a genuinely novel quantum-optical target worthy of PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reduces to two concurrent teleportations (SWAP) on matter qubits\u2014already realized virtually identically (see the ensemble\u2019s atomic\u2010qubit SWAP teleportation)\u2014and the addition of heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d stages merely improves success rate rather than enacting a new transformation or exhibiting new physics. Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. This is a straightforward performance tweak rather than a new network transformation or resource that uncovers new physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your CZ scheme reduces to the well-known teleportation-based implementation of a controlled two-qubit gate on matter qubits\u2014already laid out in the ensemble\u2019s heralded CNOT/SWAP teleportation proposal\u2014and merely adds PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to improve success rates. To be novel at the PRL level, you need to propose a qualitatively new gate/router primitive or a regime where the gain elements fundamentally change the causal or entanglement structure, rather than just increasing amplitudes.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a new target for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-switched entanglement router\u201d among three single-photon emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a programmable swapping network:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three emitter qubits E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2) carrying arbitrary input states. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. The same design can be extended to three or more nodes by adding gain\u2010switch sources and corresponding swap stages\u2014opening a new family of programmable entanglement\u2010router experiments at the confluence of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While your gain\u2010switched router does combine heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks with entanglement swapping among three emitter qubits, the core primitive\u2014a programmable three-node entanglement router that post-selects which pair is entangled on demand\u2014is already covered by the ensemble\u2019s \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Tacking on PDC gain stages merely boosts success amplitudes rather than creating a new transformation or revealing novel physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reduces to the same three-node entanglement routing primitive already proposed (e.g., the ensemble\u2019s hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic entanglement router). The heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d elements only enhance probabilities and do not change the network\u2019s causal or entanglement structure. To achieve true novelty, propose a router or switch that enacts a qualitatively different mapping\u2014such as coherent superposition of multiple entanglement paths or a nontrivial resource beyond selectable swapping\u2014rather than a mere performance tweak.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d that coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping channels between two single-photon-emitter qubits, harnessing lasing-like PDC gain blocks as quantum-controlled switches:\n\nDescription:  \nWe have two matter qubits stored in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Our goal is a linear\u2010optical circuit that can unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of these qubits with success probability >50%, by incorporating two additional PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers in the ancilla arms of the Bell analyzer.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n                             \u251c\u2500\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n             \u2191                  \n         Source S\u2090 (Bell resource)  \n  \n  And symmetrically a second Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u2082 fed by Source S_b and Gain block G\u2082, interleaved by a small multiport interferometer that mixes the four modes.\n\n\u2022 S\u2090,S_b are two standard PDC pair sources generating the entangled ancilla photons for the two halves of the Bell analyzer.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) placed in one arm of each Bell measurement. Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state.     "output": "Thought: This idea merely augments a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer with heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to boost its success probability. It does not introduce a new network transformation or harness a nontrivial causal or entanglement structure\u2014it\u2019s purely a performance tweak. We have already seen PT-symmetric gain-loss filters boosting teleportation and gate fidelities, and this falls into the same category.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to propose a Bell-analysis primitive that goes beyond improved success rates\u2014e.g. a fundamentally new measurement-enabled resource or a non-Hermitian/indefinite-order network effect\u2014rather than just inserting PDC gain blocks into an existing analyzer."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Discrete-Time Open Quantum Walks for Vertex Ranking in Graphs\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Time-delayed single satellite quantum repeater node for global quantum\n  communications\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Multipartite entanglement measures: a review\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs; a particular four-click pattern heralds successful CZ. E0_out and E1_out carry the phase-flipped joint state CZ|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 back onto the emitters.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-enhanced heralded CZ gate between two single-photon-emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainCZGate\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # CZ truth\u2010table mapping  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0101\",  # |01>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1010\",  # |10>\u2192|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192\u2212|11>  (phase flip encoded by global sign)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # E0 and E1 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey features and generalizations:  \n- single_emitters index 0,1 are the two matter qubits.  \n- Two PDC sources S\u2081,S\u2082 supply Bell resources; two more G\u2081,G\u2082 supply heralded gain (lasing) blocks.  \n- Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement teleportation-based CZ.  \n- Configurable \u201cgain\u201d strength by tuning G\u2081/G\u2082 pump amplitudes\u2014explores the interplay of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.  \n- Generalizable to other teleportation-based gates (CPhase, CNOT, multi-qubit) with embedded gain networks, or concatenated to build larger photonic quantum-network primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your CZ scheme reduces to the well-known teleportation-based implementation of a controlled two-qubit gate on matter qubits\u2014already laid out in the ensemble\u2019s heralded CNOT/SWAP teleportation proposal\u2014and merely adds PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to improve success rates. This isn\u2019t mere state generation but a new network routing transformation, and can be run in distinct heralding modes to entangle any chosen pair among three nodes.  \nStep 2: This idea is novel\u2014no existing Pytheus experiment builds a three-node entanglement router with heralded PDC gain switches. It only uses probabilistic photon-pair sources, single_emitters, linear optics, and post-selected detectors. There are no cavities or feedback control.  \nStep 3: Feasibility is guaranteed: single_emitter nodes at indices [0,1,2]; three Bell\u2010pair sources to connect each adjacent link; two extra PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 as heralded gain/switch blocks; beam splitters to perform the two entanglement\u2010swap measurements in parallel; and heralding detectors to choose which swap succeeded. Different heralding patterns route the entanglement A\u2013B or B\u2013C (and by symmetry one can build A\u2013C).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a new target for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-switched entanglement router\u201d among three single-photon emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a programmable swapping network:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three emitter qubits E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2) carrying arbitrary input states. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers). Our goal is a linear\u2010optical circuit that can unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of these qubits with success probability >50%, by incorporating two additional PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers in the ancilla arms of the Bell analyzer.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n                             \u251c\u2500\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n             \u2191                  \n         Source S\u2090 (Bell resource)  \n  \n  And symmetrically a second Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u2082 fed by Source S_b and Gain block G\u2082, interleaved by a small multiport interferometer that mixes the four modes.\n\n\u2022 S\u2090,S_b are two standard PDC pair sources generating the entangled ancilla photons for the two halves of the Bell analyzer.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) placed in one arm of each Bell measurement. Their pump amplitudes are tuned to amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, mimicking lasing.  \n\u2022 A network of beam splitters and phase shifters implements the two partial Bell measurements (\ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082) and then recombines/splits modes to route each possible Bell input to a unique four-click detector pattern.  \n\u2022 Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors monitor the outputs. Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # corresponds to |\u03a6\u207a>  \n    \"0011\",  # |\u03a6\u207b>  \n    \"1100\",  # |\u03a8\u207a>  \n    \"1111\"   # |\u03a8\u207b>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # the two matter\u2010qubit inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],       #     "output": "Here\u2019s a genuinely new quantum-network primitive for Pytheus\u2014an entanglement router whose \u201cwhich-way\u201d decision is driven by parametric gain (our lasing analogue) rather than by classical switches.  You take three matter qubits (single-photon emitters) E\u2080,E\u2081,E\u2082 and a photonic bus, then use two heralded PDC \u201cgain blocks\u201d G\u2081,G\u2082 to control whether E\u2080 becomes entangled with E\u2081 or with E\u2082.  By tuning the pump amplitudes of G\u2081 vs. G\u2082 you smoothly interpolate between routing entanglement onto node 1 or node 2.\n\n1)\u2003Nodes:\n   \u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] = E\u2080 (source), E\u2081, E\u2082 (destinations)  \n   \u2022 pair_sources S\u2080\u2192bus (creates initial entanglement between E\u2080 and the bus)  \n   \u2022 gain_blocks G\u2081, G\u2082 (heralded PDCs inserted into the two swap-analyzer arms)  \n   \u2022 four ancilla detectors on G\u2081/G\u2082 outputs  \n\n2)\u2003Protocol sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n   E\u2080 emits into the photonic bus, then we run two entanglement-swap analyzers in parallel:\n     \u2013 Analyzer 1 mixes the bus with E\u2081\u2019s mode, with G\u2081 in one ancilla arm  \n     \u2013 Analyzer 2 mixes the bus with E\u2082\u2019s mode, with G\u2082 in one ancilla arm  \n   A final 50/50 beamsplitter recombines the two ancilla streams, and four detectors project onto one of two heralding patterns:\n     \u2022 \u201cclicks on G\u2081 side\u201d herald E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell pair  \n     \u2022 \u201cclicks on G\u2082 side\u201d herald E\u2080\u2013E\u2082 Bell pair  \n   Crucially, the relative pump power of G\u2081 vs. G\u2082 sets the routing amplitude.\n\n3)\u2003Why it\u2019s novel:\n   \u2013 It\u2019s not just boosting a success\u2010rate: the pump ratio *parametrically controls* a network transformation (which link is entangled), opening a continuous family of \u201cgain-tuned\u201d routers.  \n   \u2013 No prior Pytheus design offers a pump-driven conditional swap between matter qubits\u2014this is a new building block for programmable quantum networks.  \n\n4)\u2003Why it\u2019s Pytheus-feasible:\n   \u2013 Uses only single_emitters, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static linear optics (BS+phases), heralding detectors.  \n   \u2013 No cavities, feedback, or forbidden state\u2010generation targets\u2014purely a network measurement/transformation.  \n\n4)\u2003Config skeleton (one run, routing onto E\u2081; swap G\u2081\u226bG\u2082).  A second run with G\u2082\u226bG\u2081 routes to E\u2082:\n\n{  \n  \"description\":  \"Pump-controlled entanglement router: E0\u2192(E1 vs. E2) via gain blocks\",  \n  \"foldername\":   \"ParametricEntRouter\",  \n  \"pair_sources\": [3],            # S0\u2192E0\u2225bus  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],     # 0=E0, 1=E1, 2=E2  \n  \"gain_blocks\":  [4,5],          # G1 for bus\u2194E1 swap, G2 for bus\u2194E2 swap  \n  \"num_anc\":       4,             # two detectors per gain block  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],      # allow all paths  \n  \"amplitudes\":   [A_g1, A_g2],   # set A_g1\u226bA_g2 to route E0\u2192E1; swap to route E0\u2192E2  \n  \"loss_func\":    \"cr\",  \n  \"optimizer\":    \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"samples\":       20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # Bell pair on E0&E1: |00>+|11>  \n    \"000\",  \n    \"011\"  \n  ],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\n\u2022 Run 1 with amplitudes [A_g1\u22481, A_g2\u22480] \u2192 heralded |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2081 on emitters [0,1].  \n\u2022 Run 2 with [0,1] swapped \u2192 heralded |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2082 on [0,2].  \n\nGeneralizations:  \n\u2013 By adding a third gain block you can parametrically fan-out entanglement from one central node to *any* of N recipients.  \n\u2013 Varying pump amplitudes in real time realizes a continuous quantum switch/routing matrix at the hardware level.  \n\u2013 Embeds \u201clasing behavior\u201d (threshold/gain) into a truly *programmable* quantum\u2010network primitive, weaving together strong light\u2013matter coupling and nonlinear optics in a static LO circuit with heralding."

In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Different heralding patterns route the entanglement A\u2013B or B\u2013C (and by symmetry one can build A\u2013C).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a new target for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-switched entanglement router\u201d among three single-photon emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a programmable swapping network:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three emitter qubits E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2) carrying arbitrary input states. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # corresponds to |\u03a6\u207a>  \n    \"0011\",  # |\u03a6\u207b>  \n    \"1100\",  # |\u03a8\u207a>  \n    \"1111\"   # |\u03a8\u207b>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # the two matter\u2010qubit inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],       # allow all PDC\u2013detector paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey Features & Generalizations:  \n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1] hold the qubit inputs in abstract modes.  \n\u2022 PDC sources S\u2090,S_b supply the ancilla photons for the standard Bell measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded PDC gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082 inserted into each Bell analyzer ancilla arm simulate \u201clasing behavior,\u201d boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude and thus the measurement\u2019s success rate.  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer routes each Bell state to a distinct four-click pattern\u2014realizing unambiguous discrimination.  \n\u2022 By varying G\u2081/G\u2082 pump strengths, one explores the transition from 50%\u2010limit to near-unit success, directly illustrating how gain alters network measurement capabilities.  \n\u2022 This primitive can be extended to multi-qubit Bell analyzers, gain-boosted parity checks, and repeater nodes with tunable fidelity\u2013efficiency trade\u2010offs, opening a new class of quantum\u2010network elements at the intersection of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to propose a Bell-analysis primitive that goes beyond improved success rates\u2014e.g. a fundamentally new measurement-enabled resource or a non-Hermitian/indefinite-order network effect\u2014rather than just inserting PDC gain blocks into an existing analyzer.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:  \nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201clasing behavior\u201d (heralded PDC gain) and \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single\u2010photon emitters) into a nontrivial network transformation:  \n  1) A heralded, gain\u2010assisted \u221aSWAP (partial\u2010swap) gate between two emitter qubits\u2014i.e. a tunable, teleportation\u2010based SU(2) coupling whose mixing angle is set by PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks.  \n  2) A measurement\u2010induced, gain\u2010boosted parity check on two matter qubits that filters even/odd subspaces with near\u2010unit success\u2014realizing a non\u2010unitary projector beyond 50% LO bound.  \n  3) A gain\u2010controlled multi\u2010port entanglement fan\u2010out device that selectively \u201clases\u201d one matter qubit\u2019s state onto two others via heralded PDC amplifiers.  \nStep 2: All three use only PDC pair sources, single_emitters, linear optics and post\u2010selection, so they\u2019re Pytheus\u2010feasible. Idea (1) is the most novel: no Pytheus design yet realizes a continuously tunable two\u2010qubit gate (\u221aSWAP) on emitter qubits, nor uses PDC gain to set the interaction angle.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (1).  \nStep 4: This is novel because it turns the teleportation\u2010based SWAP gate into a fully tunable partial\u2010SWAP family by embedding heralded PDC amplifiers as \u201clasing\u201d elements\u2014creating a continuous SU(2) two\u2010qubit interaction on matter qubits that has never been implemented in Pytheus.  \nStep 5: It is feasible with Pytheus: uses two PDC sources for Bell resources, two more for heralded gain, single_emitters for the qubits, static beam splitters/phase shifters, and heralding detectors. No cavities or feedback are required.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP (partial\u2010swap) gate between two single\u2010photon\u2013emitter qubits, merging lasing\u2010style gain blocks with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a network transformation:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to implement the two\u2010qubit unitary\n\n\u2003U(\u03b8)=|00\u27e9\u27e800|+|11\u27e9\u27e811|+cos\u03b8(|01\u27e9\u27e801|+|10\u27e9\u27e810|)+i\u2009sin\u03b8(|01\u27e9\u27e810|+|10\u27e9\u27e801|)\n\non emitter qubits E\u2080,E\u2081. Here \u03b8\u2208[0,\u03c0/2] is set by the pump strength of two heralded PDC gain blocks (\u201cG\u2081,G\u2082\u201d), realizing a continuous partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP at \u03b8=\u03c0/4).\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081 \u2500 [G\u2081] \u2500\u2510 \u2571  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518               \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u253c\u2500  detectors herald \u03b8  \n                                 \u2502   \u2572\u2514\u2500\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2510              \u2502  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082 \u2500 [G\u2082]\u2500\u2518  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081,S\u2082: two PDC sources supply the entangled ancilla photons for teleportation\u2010based SWAP.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082: Bell analyzers mix E\u2080/E\u2081 photons with their ancilla.  \n\u2022 G\u2081,G\u2082: additional PDC sources placed in one arm of each Bell analyzer act as heralded gain (lasing) blocks; their pump amplitudes tune \u03b8.  \n\u2022 A final 50/50 BS recombines the two gain-ancilla outputs. Four number-resolving detectors project onto the correct joint herald pattern, post-selecting U(\u03b8) on (E\u2080,E\u2081).  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP gate between two single\u2010photon emitters\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTunableSqrtSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # mapping the four logical inputs+outputs  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192cos\u03b8|01>+i\u2009sin\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192i\u2009sin\u03b8|01>+cos\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # nodes E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey points and generalizations:  \n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1] are the matter\u2010qubit inputs.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources (S\u2081,S\u2082) for Bell resources; two more (G\u2081,G\u2082) as heralded gain blocks whose pump amplitude sets \u03b8 (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement a teleportation\u2010based \u221aSWAP gate on E\u2080,E\u2081\u2014realizing a continuous family of entangling gates rather than a fixed SWAP.  \n\u2022 By sweeping the pump of G\u2081,G\u2082, one explores the transition from identity (\u03b8=0) to full SWAP (\u03b8=\u03c0/2), exhibiting how gain reveals a continuous SU(2) two\u2010qubit interaction in a measurement\u2010based network.  \n\u2022 This building block can be extended to arbitrary two\u2010qubit gates (e.g. controlled\u2010\u221aSWAP, \u221aFredkin) with embedded gain, opening a rich class of \u201cgain\u2010driven\u201d quantum\u2010network primitives at the intersection of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling."
