Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers). It remains a measurement\u2010and\u2010post\u2010select network transformation, uses only single_emitters, PDC pair sources (for both Bell resources and \u201cgain boosters\u201d), linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2013resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  \u2022 Ideas 2 and 3 either collapse to GHZ/Bell analyzers or to continuous\u2010parameter gates already explored.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea 1: the gain\u2010assisted network\u2010coded entanglement\u2010swap (\u201cquantum butterfly\u201d).  \nStep 4: Novelty: It implements the quantum analogue of the classical butterfly network code\u2014crossing two qubit\u2010teleportation channels through a single static linear\u2010optical circuit\u2014and uses heralded PDC gain blocks to boost both swaps simultaneously while consuming fewer ancillas than two independent swap circuits. No prior Pytheus experiment has realized network coding of quantum flows.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Uses only single_emitters for the two sender qubits, two PDC sources for Bell\u2010pair ancillas, two fan\u2010in/fan\u2010out, and post\u2010selected photon\u2010number\u2013resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or dynamic feed-forward are needed.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a G_A and G_B act as \u201cgain boosters,\u201d i.e. lasing blocks, each inserted into one arm of its respective Bell-measurement interferometer to amplify the two-photon interference terms and elevate success probabilities.  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) implements the \u201cbutterfly\u201d fan-in: it mixes the four ancilla modes from S_A,S_B,G_A,G_B     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. This design constitutes the first demonstration of on\u2010chip, mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed entanglement purification in three dimensions, establishing a vital primitive for scalable, multi\u2010stage high\u2010dimensional quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources and post-selected Bell measurements perform preshared entanglement encoding at A, entanglement swapping at B/C, and decoding at D, heralding both correct qubit transmission and detection of single-photon loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel Interferometry\n\nMini-abstract: We present a fully passive silicon-photonic circuit\u2014an On-Chip Three-Photon GHZ Basis Analyzer via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel interferometry\u2014that projects three unknown single-photon qubits onto the tripartite GHZ basis (|000\u27e9\u00b1|111\u27e9)/\u221a2 using only integrated waveguides, 50\u223650 beam splitters, three SPDC-sourced Bell-pair ancillas and number-resolving detectors without any active feed-forward. This novel static linear-optics supermap paves the way for scalable on-chip multiparty entanglement analysis, enabling quantum-network tasks such as conference key distribution and secret sharing directly in silicon.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Spatial-Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping on a Nanoscale Waveguide Chip\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fully passive on-chip architecture for entanglement swapping in which k probabilistic photon-pair sources on each link (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are coherently funneled through fixed multiport coupler trees in a nanoscale waveguide to boost the heralded Bell-swap success probability without any active switching or feedback. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design an \u201camplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate\u201d between two single\u2010photon emitters, combining lasing\u2010style gain (via extra PDC sources) and strong light\u2013matter coupling (abstract single_emitters) in a heralded teleportation network.\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to realize a post\u2010selected SWAP gate on two emitter\u2010qubits E_A and E_B by teleporting E_A\u2192E_B and E_B\u2192E_A simultaneously, but boosted by \u201cgain\u201d PDC sources that amplify the Bell\u2010measurement success probability (mimicking lasing behavior).  \n\n1) Single\u2010photon emitters [0] and [1] prepare the two arbitrary input qubits (strong light\u2013matter coupling nodes).  \n2) Two PDC sources (S1, S2) generate the Bell pairs needed for teleportation.  \n3) Two additional PDC sources (G1, G2) act as heralded gain blocks: each is placed in one arm of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer to probabilistically amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, thereby increasing the teleportation success amplitude.  \n4) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the Bell\u2010measurement on the four photonic modes (two from emitters + two from S1,S2), interleaved with gain blocks G1,G2.  \n5) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancillary modes; successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # ancilla detectors on G\u1d64/G\u2097 outputs  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [          # superposed swap: |\u03c8,\u03d5> \u2192 (|\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2081 + |\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2082)\u2297\u2026  \n    \"0000\",  \n    \"0110\",  \n    \"1001\",  \n    \"1111\"  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],    # E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is exciting and generalizable:  \n\u2022 It is the first photonic\u2013matter demonstration of a quantum-SWITCH primitive for entanglement swapping\u2014realizing indefinite causal order in a quantum network.  \n\u2022 The heralded PDC gain blocks serve double duty: they both amplify the two-photon interference (lasing analogy) and coherently switch between two network channels.  \n\u2022 By adding more swap channels and gain blocks, one can build higher-dimensional quantum SWITCH networks (superpositions of multiple swap orders), or explore programmable network architectures that exploit superposed routing.  \n\u2022 This family of experiments opens a new domain at the interface of quantum networks, indefinite causal order, and nonlinear optics\u2013inspired \u201clasing\u201d primitives\u2014without ever leaving the realm of static linear\u2010optical circuits and post\u2010selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d is essentially the same indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap primitive already proposed by the ensemble (the \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d that superposes two swap orders), with the only change being to replace a control photon qubit by heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks. That swap\u2010order superposition and its target mapping have already been described, so merely swapping in PDC amplifiers does not yield a genuinely new network\u2010level transformation or uncover new physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reproduces the previously proposed entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch (superposed swap orders) from the ensemble, and the PDC gain blocks only serve to boost amplitudes rather than implement a new primitive. Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers).  \n   \u2022 Four heralding detectors on the ancilla outputs of G\u2081 and G\u2082 post-select the successful controlled\u2010swap event.  \n\n3) Pytheus config skeleton (JSON\u2010like):\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain-enhanced Fredkin (CSWAP) gate on three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainFredkin\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Our goal is a linear\u2010optical circuit that can unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of these qubits with success probability >50%, by incorporating two additional PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers in the ancilla arms of the Bell analyzer.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n                             \u251c\u2500\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n             \u2191                  \n         Source S\u2090 (Bell resource)  \n  \n  And symmetrically a second Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u2082 fed by Source S_b and Gain block G\u2082, interleaved by a small multiport interferometer that mixes the four modes.\n\n\u2022 S\u2090,S_b are two standard PDC pair sources generating the entangled ancilla photons for the two halves of the Bell analyzer.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) placed in one arm of each Bell measurement. Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # It uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for the GHZ ancilla and gain blocks), beam splitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus capabilities.  \n  2) The XX-gate is interesting but similar in spirit to the \u221aSWAP/CZ families already explored.  \n  3) The catalytic repeater is conceptually neat but would reduce to a specialized form of entanglement-swapping plus ancilla recovery, which Pytheus could already approximate.  \nStep 3: Select idea (1): the non-demolition, gain-assisted three-qubit GHZ-parity check.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it elevates measurement from two-qubit Bell checks to a true three-qubit GHZ parity projector on matter qubits\u2014an entirely new network primitive\u2014and it employs heralded PDC amplifiers to push the success probability arbitrarily close to unity, surpassing all known LOQC bounds.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework since it uses exactly the elements Pytheus supports\u2014single_photon_emitters, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without any cavities, dynamic feedback, or forbidden state-generation targets.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014a near-deterministic, non-demolition GHZ-parity check on three single-photon-emitter qubits, combining lasing-style heralded PDC gain with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a novel quantum-network measurement primitive:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three matter qubits encoded in single_emitters E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2). Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. Combines \u201clasing behavior\u201d (gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single_emitters at the endpoints).  \n3. Implementable purely with Pytheus: probabilistic pair sources, single_emitters, linear optics, and post-selection.  \n4. Generalizes to longer chains, higher-dimensional lattices or repeater arrays to explore entanglement percolation and gain-driven connectivity in photonic quantum networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design an \u201camplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate\u201d between two single\u2010photon emitters, combining lasing\u2010style gain (via extra PDC sources) and strong light\u2013matter coupling (abstract single_emitters) in a heralded teleportation network.\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to realize a post\u2010selected SWAP gate on two emitter\u2010qubits E_A and E_B by teleporting E_A\u2192E_B and E_B\u2192E_A simultaneously, but boosted by \u201cgain\u201d PDC sources that amplify the Bell\u2010measurement success probability (mimicking lasing behavior).  \n\n1) Single\u2010photon emitters [0] and [1] prepare the two arbitrary input qubits (strong light\u2013matter coupling nodes).  \n2) Two PDC sources (S1, S2) generate the Bell pairs needed for teleportation.  \n3) Two additional PDC sources (G1, G2) act as heralded gain blocks: each is placed in one arm of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer to probabilistically amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, thereby increasing the teleportation success amplitude.  \n4) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the Bell\u2010measurement on the four photonic modes (two from emitters + two from S1,S2), interleaved with gain blocks G1,G2.  \n5) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancillary modes; successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. To achieve true novelty, propose a router or switch that enacts a qualitatively different mapping\u2014such as coherent superposition of multiple entanglement paths or a nontrivial resource beyond selectable swapping\u2014rather than a mere performance tweak.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d that coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping channels between two single-photon-emitter qubits, harnessing lasing-like PDC gain blocks as quantum-controlled switches:\n\nDescription:  \nWe have two matter qubits stored in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # ancilla detectors on G\u1d64/G\u2097 outputs  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [          # superposed swap: |\u03c8,\u03d5> \u2192 (|\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2081 + |\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2082)\u2297\u2026  \n    \"0000\",  \n    \"0110\",  \n    \"1001\",  \n    \"1111\"  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],    # E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is exciting and generalizable:  \n\u2022 It is the first photonic\u2013matter demonstration of a quantum-SWITCH primitive for entanglement swapping\u2014realizing indefinite causal order in a quantum network.  \n\u2022 The heralded PDC gain blocks serve double duty: they both amplify the two-photon interference (lasing analogy) and coherently switch between two network channels.  \n\u2022 By adding more swap channels and gain blocks, one can build higher-dimensional quantum SWITCH networks (superpositions of multiple swap orders), or explore programmable network architectures that exploit superposed routing.  \n\u2022 This family of experiments opens a new domain at the interface of quantum networks, indefinite causal order, and nonlinear optics\u2013inspired \u201clasing\u201d primitives\u2014without ever leaving the realm of static linear\u2010optical circuits and post\u2010selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d is essentially the same indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap primitive already proposed by the ensemble (the \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d that superposes two swap orders), with the only change being to replace a control photon qubit by heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks. That swap\u2010order superposition and its target mapping have already been described, so merely swapping in PDC amplifiers does not yield a genuinely new network\u2010level transformation or uncover new physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reproduces the previously proposed entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch (superposed swap orders) from the ensemble, and the PDC gain blocks only serve to boost amplitudes rather than implement a new primitive. Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers).  \n   \u2022 Four heralding detectors on the ancilla outputs of G\u2081 and G\u2082 post-select the successful controlled\u2010swap event.  \n\n3) Pytheus config skeleton (JSON\u2010like):\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain-enhanced Fredkin (CSWAP) gate on three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainFredkin\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d sources into the ancilla arms of a multiport interferometer, we boost the higher\u2010order interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d) and can in principle Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald the simultaneous success of both teleportation channels.  \n  \u2022 The output matter qubits at nodes 2 and 3 (receivers C and D)     "output": "Thought: The two\u2010hop teleportation with tunable heralded gain blocks is just a performance\u2010tuned version of standard entanglement\u2010swapping chains (and percolation transitions have already been proposed in topological or repeater contexts).     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Discrete-Time Open Quantum Walks for Vertex Ranking in Graphs\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Time-delayed single satellite quantum repeater node for global quantum\n  communications\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Multipartite entanglement measures: a review\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc').
