successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n                        \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G1]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510  detectors         \nemitters:  [Emitter 1] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2518               \u2502  \u2514\u2500[G2]\u2500(Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2014\u2510  \n                                         \u2502                 \u2514\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_A]  \nBell-sources S1,S2 feed the middle of each Bell circuit; Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs; a particular four-click pattern heralds successful CZ. E0_out and E1_out carry the phase-flipped joint state CZ|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 back onto the emitters.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-enhanced heralded CZ gate between two single-photon-emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainCZGate\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # CZ truth\u2010table mapping  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0101\",  # |01>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1010\",  # |10>\u2192|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192\u2212|11>  (phase flip encoded by global sign)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # E0 and E1 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey features and generalizations:  \n- single_emitters index 0,1 are the two matter qubits.  \n- Two PDC sources S\u2081,S\u2082 supply Bell resources; two more G\u2081,G\u2082 supply heralded gain (lasing) blocks.  \n- Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement teleportation-based CZ.  \n- Configurable \u201cgain\u201d strength by tuning G\u2081/G\u2082 pump amplitudes\u2014explores the interplay of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.  \n- Generalizable to other teleportation-based gates (CPhase, CNOT, multi-qubit) with embedded gain networks, or concatenated to build larger photonic quantum-network primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your CZ scheme reduces to the well-known teleportation-based implementation of a controlled two-qubit gate on matter qubits\u2014already laid out in the ensemble\u2019s heralded CNOT/SWAP teleportation proposal\u2014and merely adds PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to improve success rates. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # when E\u2080=|0\u27e9, the Bell analyzers are effectively bypassed (identity).  \n\u2022 G\u2081, G\u2082 act as heralded gain amplifiers to boost the small-amplitude two\u2010photon interference events, mimicking lasing behavior.  \n\u2022 Four heralding clicks indicate a successful Fredkin.  \n\n5) Generalizations:  \n  \u2013 Varying pump amplitudes on G\u2081/G\u2082 to study threshold behavior in gate success (\u201claser threshold\u201d analogy).  \n  \u2013 Cascading multiple Fredkins yields larger universal networks with integrated gain elements.  \n  \u2013 Embedding this building block into repeater chains or measurement\u2010based circuits demonstrates scalable, gain\u2010assisted quantum networks combining lasing physics and strong emitter coupling.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the known heralded Fredkin primitive while using PDC gain blocks only as probabilistic \u201camplitude boosters.\u201d To be novel at the first design of a three\u2010qubit GHZ analyzer in linear\u2010optical quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Heralded PDC gain blocks serve as \u201clasing\u201d amplifiers of higher\u2010order discrimination\u2014a new fundamental test of how gain modifies quantum\u2010network measurement power.  \n\u2022 The same architecture extends to four\u2010qubit cluster\u2010state analyzers or to partial GHZ\u2010parity checks, opening a broad class of gain\u2010augmented measurement primitives for quantum networks.\n\nThis target is fully implementable by Pytheus using only probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, static linear optics, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or dynamic feedback.                  \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500[3]  \n                 \u251c\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524      (emitters A/B)  \n  Bell source S\u2081\u2500\u2518                \u2502  \n                                  \u251c\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082\u2500\u2500[G\u2082]  \n  Bell source S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n             \u2191  \n         intermediate mode [1] & [2]  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081, S\u2082 are two standard PDC sources generating Bell pairs for the first and second swap hops.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081 mixes emitter A\u2019s photon with one photon of S\u2081; \ud835\udcd1\u2082 mixes the outgoing mode of hop-1 (mode [1]) with one photon of S\u2082.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional heralded PDC gain blocks inserted into the second arm of each \ud835\udcd1-measurement; their pump amplitudes set the effective gain.  \n\u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla arms post-select successful two-hop teleportation.  \n\u2022 By tuning pump strength of G\u2081,G\u2082, the probability that both swaps succeed exhibits a sharp threshold\u2014a lasing-like percolation phase transition in network reachability.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Two-hop teleportation with heralded PDC gain \u2013 percolation threshold demo\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTeleportChain\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n Demonstrates a genuine network phenomenon\u2014a percolation or phase-transition in teleportation fidelity\u2014as heralded PDC gain crosses a critical threshold.  \n2. Combines \u201clasing behavior\u201d (gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single_emitters at the endpoints).  \n3.     "output": "Here is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain-assisted entanglement\u2010distillation\u2010swapping node that takes two probabilistic Bell links between four single-photon emitters (strong light\u2013matter qubits) and, in one static linear-optics circuit, both swaps and \u201cpurifies\u201d them into a higher-fidelity Bell pair between the two end nodes. By inserting heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks (our lasing analogue) into the swap measurement, one can push the output fidelity above what any passive LOQC repeater node can achieve\u2014demonstrating a qualitatively new network transformation (entanglement distillation + swapping) rather than mere state generation.\n\n1) Conceptual Sketch  \nWe have four matter\u2010qubit nodes (single_emitters):  \n  \u2022 E\u2080 (node 0) and E\u2081 (node 1) are linked by a noisy Bell pair from PDC source S\u2081.  \n  \u2022 E\u2082 (node 2) and E\u2083 (node 3) are linked by a noisy Bell pair from PDC source S\u2082.  \nWe perform a joint swap-and-distill measurement on the two middle photons (from E\u2081 and E\u2082) using a linear-optical Bell\u2013analyzer augmented by two heralded gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082. Conditioned on a particular four-click pattern, E\u2080 and E\u2083 emerge projected into a purified Bell pair with higher fidelity than S\u2081 or S\u2082 alone.\n\n           PDC S\u2081               PDC S\u2082  \n   [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2572              \u2571\u2500\u2500[E\u2083]  \n         BS\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2013[G\u2081]\u2013\u2510  \u250c\u2013[G\u2082]\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082\u2013BS  \n   [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2571              \u2572\u2500\u2500[E\u2082]  \n           herald detectors (4 clicks)  \n\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits a photon to E\u2080 and one to the \ud835\udcd1\u2081 analyzer; S\u2082 likewise feeds E\u2083 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082.  \n \u2022 The two \u201csignal\u201d modes from E\u2081 and E\u2082 (the matter\u2010qubit photons) are mixed into \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082 respectively.  \n \u2022 In each Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u1d62, one arm passes through a PDC gain source G\u1d62 (pump\u2010tunable), amplifying the two-photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n \u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald a successful swap+distillation event.  \n \u2022 Upon herald, qubits E\u2080 and E\u2083 (the two end emitters) share a Bell state of fidelity F_out > max(F_S\u2081,F_S\u2082).\n\n2) Why It\u2019s New  \n \u2022 No existing Pytheus experiment fuses entanglement swapping with active distillation in a single static network.  \n \u2022 Heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks do more than boost success probability: they selectively amplify the desired joint\u2010parity components in the swap measurement, raising output fidelity above passive limits.  \n \u2022 This constitutes a new two\u2010node network primitive\u2014\u201cdistill\u2010and\u2010swap node\u201d\u2014not just a state generator or a standard gate.  \n \u2022 By varying the pump strengths of G\u2081/G\u2082 one observes a \u201cpercolation\u201d or \u201claser-threshold\u201d\u2013like onset of high\u2010fidelity end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement, illustrating the interplay of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\n3) Pytheus Config Skeleton  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted entanglement-distillation-swapping node between emitters 0 and 3\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainDistillSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # end-to-end Bell on nodes [0,3]  \n    \"0000\",                         # |00>\u2080\u2083  \n    \"0110\",                         # |01>\u2080\u2083  \n    \"1001\",                         # |10>\u2080\u2083  \n    \"1111\"                          # |11>\u2080\u2083  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2,3],     # four matter qubit modes  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all PDC\u2192detector paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\n4) Generalizations  \n \u2022 Chain multiple distill-swap nodes into a linear repeater with in-line \u201clasing\u201d gain, exploring fidelity thresholds vs. pump.  \n \u2022 Extend to 2D networks, studying entanglement percolation with gain\u2010assisted links.  \n \u2022 Replace one PDC gain block with a loss block to study non-Hermitian distillation networks.  \n\nAll elements\u2014single-photon emitters (nodes), probabilistic PDC pair sources (S\u2081,S\u2082), heralded PDC gain blocks (G\u2081,G\u2082), static beam splitters/phase shifters, and post-selection via photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014are fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. This opens a new family of quantum\u2010network primitives at the intersection of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling."

It only uses probabilistic photon-pair sources, single_emitters, linear optics, and post-selected detectors. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two swap channels and gain switches), single_emitters, linear-optics interferometers, and heralding detectors.  \n  b) The cascaded teleportation is too similar to sequential swap/distillation experiments already explored.  \n  c) The entanglement multiplexer reduces to state routing rather than a fundamentally new superposed process.  \nStep 3: Choose idea (a) \u2013 the \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH for entanglement swapping.\u201d  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement-swapping operations on matter qubits\u2014a demonstration of indefinite causal order in a quantum network\u2014using only linear optics, heralded PDC gain blocks, and single-photon emitters. No prior Pytheus experiment has explored such a superposed network transformation.  \nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework since it requires:  \n  \u2022 single_emitters for the two matter-qubit inputs,  \n  \u2022 four PDC pair-sources (two for the swap channels, two as heralded gain/switch blocks),  \n  \u2022 a static linear-optical interferometer to coherently split and recombine the ancilla photon through the two swap routes, and  \n  \u2022 post-selection on heralding detectors to project onto the coherent superposition of swap outcomes.  \nNo cavities, no active feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d that coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping channels between two single-photon-emitter qubits, harnessing lasing-like PDC gain blocks as quantum-controlled switches:\n\nDescription:  \nWe have two matter qubits stored in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Here \u03b8\u2208[0,\u03c0/2] is set by the pump strength of two heralded PDC gain blocks (\u201cG\u2081,G\u2082\u201d), realizing a continuous partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP at \u03b8=\u03c0/4).\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081 \u2500 [G\u2081] \u2500\u2510 \u2571  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518               \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u253c\u2500  detectors herald \u03b8  \n                                 \u2502   \u2572\u2514\u2500\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2510              \u2502  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082 \u2500 [G\u2082]\u2500\u2518  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081,S\u2082: two PDC sources supply the entangled ancilla photons for teleportation\u2010based SWAP.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082: Bell analyzers mix E\u2080/E\u2081 photons with their ancilla.  \n\u2022 G\u2081,G\u2082: additional PDC sources placed in one arm of each Bell analyzer act as heralded gain (lasing) blocks; their pump amplitudes tune \u03b8.  \n\u2022 A final 50/50 BS recombines the two gain-ancilla outputs. It uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for the GHZ ancilla and gain blocks), beam splitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus capabilities.  \n  2) The XX-gate is interesting but similar in spirit to the \u221aSWAP/CZ families already explored.  \n  3) The catalytic repeater is conceptually neat but would reduce to a specialized form of entanglement-swapping plus ancilla recovery, which Pytheus could already approximate.  \nStep 3: Select idea (1): the non-demolition, gain-assisted three-qubit GHZ-parity check.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it elevates measurement from two-qubit Bell checks to a true three-qubit GHZ parity projector on matter qubits\u2014an entirely new network primitive\u2014and it employs heralded PDC amplifiers to push the success probability arbitrarily close to unity, surpassing all known LOQC bounds.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework since it uses exactly the elements Pytheus supports\u2014single_photon_emitters, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without any cavities, dynamic feedback, or forbidden state-generation targets.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014a near-deterministic, non-demolition GHZ-parity check on three single-photon-emitter qubits, combining lasing-style heralded PDC gain with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a novel quantum-network measurement primitive:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three matter qubits encoded in single_emitters E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2). Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. Four photon-number-resolving detectors monitor the ancilla outputs.  \n\u2022 A specific click pattern on these detectors heralds P_GHZ=+1 (even GHZ parity); the complementary pattern heralds P_GHZ=\u22121.  \n\u2022 Crucially, the matter qubits themselves are left intact\u2014projected non-destructively into the corresponding GHZ parity subspace\u2014enabling mid-circuit syndrome extraction or adaptive network protocols.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Non-demolition, gain-assisted GHZ-parity check for three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainGHZParity\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # It remains a measurement\u2010and\u2010post\u2010select network transformation, uses only single_emitters, PDC pair sources (for both Bell resources and \u201cgain boosters\u201d), linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2013resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  \u2022 Ideas 2 and 3 either collapse to GHZ/Bell analyzers or to continuous\u2010parameter gates already explored.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea 1: the gain\u2010assisted network\u2010coded entanglement\u2010swap (\u201cquantum butterfly\u201d).  \nStep 4: Novelty: It implements the quantum analogue of the classical butterfly network code\u2014crossing two qubit\u2010teleportation channels through a single static linear\u2010optical circuit\u2014and uses heralded PDC gain blocks to boost both swaps simultaneously while consuming fewer ancillas than two independent swap circuits. success probabilities.  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) implements the \u201cbutterfly\u201d fan-in: it mixes the four ancilla modes from S_A,S_B,G_A,G_B This goes beyond simple teleportation or state generation, uses only static linear optics, PDC pair sources, single_emitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, and opens a family of nested, gain-tunable distillation protocols.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a target for Pytheus\u2014a gain-assisted entanglement-distillation module between two distant single-photon\u2013emitter qubits:\n\n1) Task  \nWe have two initial noisy Bell pairs shared between matter qubit nodes A and B:  \n  \u2022 A holds emitters E\u2080 and E\u2082 (nodes 0,2).  \n  \u2022 B holds emitters E\u2081 and E\u2083 (nodes 1,3).  \nGoal: distill a single, higher-fidelity Bell pair between E\u2080 and E\u2081 by consuming the second pair (E\u2082\u2013E\u2083) in a gain-enhanced Bell measurement.\n\n2) Resources  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0,1,2,3] for E\u2080,E\u2081,E\u2082,E\u2083.  \n  \u2022 Two PDC pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082 generate the noisy Bell pairs between (E\u2080\u2013E\u2081) and (E\u2082\u2013E\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081 and G\u2082 serve as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers, inserted into the two ancilla arms of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer on E\u2082\u2013E\u2083. Their pump amplitudes tune the effective gain (lasing analogue).  \n  \u2022 A linear-optical Bell\u2010analyzer \ud835\udcd1 mixes photons from E\u2082 and E\u2083 with one photon each from G\u2081 and G\u2082.  \n  \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald a successful projection onto the \u201ceven\u201d Bell subspace of E\u2082\u2013E\u2083, which\u2014upon post-selection\u2014projects E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 onto a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.  \n\n3) Network Sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2082]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                      \n                  \u251c\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n  Bell source S\u2082\u2500\u2518                \u251c\u2500 detectors for distillation herald  \n                                  \u2514\u2500\u2500[G\u2082]  \n emitters: [E\u2083]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\nMeanwhile E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 remain untouched until herald fires; then E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 collapse into the distilled Bell pair.\n\n4) Pytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted distillation node for two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainDistillNode\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                       # four detectors on the distillation Bell\u2010analyzer  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                 # heralding patterns corresponding to the <\u03a6+| projection on E\u2082\u2013E\u2083  \n    \"2000\",  # two photons in detector0  \n    \"0200\",  \n    \"0020\",  \n    \"0002\"  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [2,3],           # E\u2082 and E\u2083 are measured  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\n5) Why It\u2019s Novel & Generalizable  \n  \u2022 First-ever heralded, gain-boosted entanglement distillation node in photonic quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 PDC gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082 implement \u201clasing behavior,\u201d amplifying constructive interference in the distillation measurement and boosting both success probability and output fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Only static linear optics, probabilistic PDC sources, single_emitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  \u2022 Can be nested: multiple such nodes chained or concatenated yield multi-round distillation protocols, tunable by gain pump strengths\u2014exploring threshold effects and percolation of high-fidelity links in repeater networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design an \u201camplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate\u201d between two single\u2010photon emitters, combining lasing\u2010style gain (via extra PDC sources) and strong light\u2013matter coupling (abstract single_emitters) in a heralded teleportation network.\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to realize a post\u2010selected SWAP gate on two emitter\u2010qubits E_A and E_B by teleporting E_A\u2192E_B and E_B\u2192E_A simultaneously, but boosted by \u201cgain\u201d PDC sources that amplify the Bell\u2010measurement success probability (mimicking lasing behavior).  \n\n1) Single\u2010photon emitters [0] and [1] prepare the two arbitrary input qubits (strong light\u2013matter coupling nodes).  \n2) Two PDC sources (S1, S2) generate the Bell pairs needed for teleportation.  \n3) Two additional PDC sources (G1, G2) act as heralded gain blocks: each is placed in one arm of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer to probabilistically amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, thereby increasing the teleportation success amplitude.  \n4) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the Bell\u2010measurement on the four photonic modes (two from emitters + two from S1,S2), interleaved with gain blocks G1,G2.  \n5) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancillary modes; successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. To be novel at the PRL level, you need to propose a qualitatively new gate/router primitive or a regime where the gain elements fundamentally change the causal or entanglement structure, rather than just increasing amplitudes.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a new target for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-switched entanglement router\u201d among three single-photon emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a programmable swapping network:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three emitter qubits E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2) carrying arbitrary input states. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. The same design can be extended to three or more nodes by adding gain\u2010switch sources and corresponding swap stages\u2014opening a new family of programmable entanglement\u2010router experiments at the confluence of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While your gain\u2010switched router does combine heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks with entanglement swapping among three emitter qubits, the core primitive\u2014a programmable three-node entanglement router that post-selects which pair is entangled on demand\u2014is already covered by the ensemble\u2019s \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Tacking on PDC gain stages merely boosts success amplitudes rather than creating a new transformation or revealing novel physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reduces to the same three-node entanglement routing primitive already proposed (e.g., the ensemble\u2019s hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic entanglement router). The heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d elements only enhance probabilities and do not change the network\u2019s causal or entanglement structure. To achieve true novelty, propose a router or switch that enacts a qualitatively different mapping\u2014such as coherent superposition of multiple entanglement paths or a nontrivial resource beyond selectable swapping\u2014rather than a mere performance tweak.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d that coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping channels between two single-photon-emitter qubits, harnessing lasing-like PDC gain blocks as quantum-controlled switches:\n\nDescription:  \nWe have two matter qubits stored in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is exciting and generalizable:  \n\u2022 It is the first photonic\u2013matter demonstration of a quantum-SWITCH primitive for entanglement swapping\u2014realizing indefinite causal order in a quantum network.  \n\u2022 The heralded PDC gain blocks serve double duty: they both amplify the two-photon interference (lasing analogy) and coherently switch between two network channels.  \n\u2022 By adding more swap channels and gain blocks, one can build higher-dimensional quantum SWITCH networks (superpositions of multiple swap orders), or explore programmable network architectures that exploit superposed routing.  \n\u2022 This family of experiments opens a new domain at the interface of quantum networks, indefinite causal order, and nonlinear optics\u2013inspired \u201clasing\u201d primitives\u2014without ever leaving the realm of static linear\u2010optical circuits and post\u2010selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d is essentially the same indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap primitive already proposed by the ensemble (the \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d that superposes two swap orders), with the only change being to replace a control photon qubit by heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks. Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers).  \n   \u2022 Four heralding detectors on the ancilla outputs of G\u2081 and G\u2082 post-select the successful controlled\u2010swap event.  \n\n3) Pytheus config skeleton (JSON\u2010like):\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain-enhanced Fredkin (CSWAP) gate on three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainFredkin\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # Here \u03b8\u2208[0,\u03c0/2] is set by the pump strength of two heralded PDC gain blocks (\u201cG\u2081,G\u2082\u201d), realizing a continuous partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP at \u03b8=\u03c0/4).\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081 \u2500 [G\u2081] \u2500\u2510 \u2571  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518               \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u253c\u2500  detectors herald \u03b8  \n                                 \u2502   \u2572\u2514\u2500\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2510              \u2502  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082 \u2500 [G\u2082]\u2500\u2518  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081,S\u2082: two PDC sources supply the entangled ancilla photons for teleportation\u2010based SWAP.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082: Bell analyzers mix E\u2080/E\u2081 photons with their ancilla.  \n\u2022 G\u2081,G\u2082: additional PDC sources placed in one arm of each Bell analyzer act as heralded gain (lasing) blocks; their pump amplitudes tune \u03b8.  \n\u2022 A final 50/50 BS recombines the two gain-ancilla outputs. Four number-resolving detectors project onto the correct joint herald pattern, post-selecting U(\u03b8) on (E\u2080,E\u2081).  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP gate between two single\u2010photon emitters\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTunableSqrtSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # mapping the four logical inputs+outputs  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192cos\u03b8|01>+i\u2009sin\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192i\u2009sin\u03b8|01>+cos\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # nodes E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey points and generalizations:  \n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1] are the matter\u2010qubit inputs.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources (S\u2081,S\u2082) for Bell resources; two more (G\u2081,G\u2082) as heralded gain blocks whose pump amplitude sets \u03b8 (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement a teleportation\u2010based \u221aSWAP gate on E\u2080,E\u2081\u2014realizing a continuous family of entangling gates rather than a fixed SWAP.  \n\u2022 By sweeping the pump of G\u2081,G\u2082, one explores the transition from identity (\u03b8=0) to full SWAP (\u03b8=\u03c0/2), exhibiting how gain reveals a continuous SU(2) two\u2010qubit interaction in a measurement\u2010based network.  \n\u2022 This building block can be extended to arbitrary two\u2010qubit gates (e.g. controlled\u2010\u221aSWAP, \u221aFredkin) with embedded gain, opening a rich class of \u201cgain\u2010driven\u201d quantum\u2010network primitives at the intersection of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cgain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP\u201d is nothing more than the ensemble\u2019s heralded partial-SWAP primitive\u2014with the only twist being insertion of PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to boost the success amplitude. Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a gain-assisted GHZ-basis analyzer for three single-photon\u2013emitter qubits, combining lasing-style heralded PDC gain blocks with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a genuinely new measurement primitive:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe wish to unambiguously discriminate all eight three-qubit GHZ basis states of emitter qubits E\u2080,E\u2081,E\u2082:\n\n  |\u03a6\u2080^\u00b1\u27e9 = |000\u27e9\u00b1|111\u27e9  \n  |\u03a6\u2081^\u00b1\u27e9 = |001\u27e9\u00b1|110\u27e9  \n  |\u03a6\u2082^\u00b1\u27e9 = |010\u27e9\u00b1|101\u27e9  \n  |\u03a6\u2083^\u00b1\u27e9 = |011\u27e9\u00b1|100\u27e9  \n\nStandard linear optics limits one to at most 2^n\u22121=4 unambiguous outcomes for n=3; by embedding two heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d sources into the ancilla arms of a multiport interferometer, we boost the higher\u2010order interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d) and can in principle resolve all eight GHZ states.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500[Detectors 0,1]  \n pair sources S\u2090,S\u1d66 generate the ancilla photons for GHZ projection.  \n\u2022 Gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082 (additional heralded PDC sources) sit in each ancilla arm of the GHZ analyzer \ud835\udcd6, amplifying the three\u2010photon interference terms.  \n\u2022 A fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters splits and recombines the five modes; four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors monitor the outputs.  \n\u2022 Each of the eight possible click patterns (one unique 4-click signature among detectors 0\u20133) corresponds unambiguously to one GHZ basis state.  \n\nBy tuning the pump amplitudes of G\u2081,G\u2082, one explores the transition from the standard 4\u2010outcome limit to full 8\u2010outcome discrimination\u2014demonstrating how \u201clasing behavior\u201d fundamentally extends the measurement power of linear\u2010optical quantum networks.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. We wish to enact the non-unitary transformation\n  U(2)=|00\u27e9\u27e800|+|11\u27e9\u27e811|+2\u2009|01\u27e9\u27e810|+\u00bd\u2009|10\u27e9\u27e801|  \nby a static linear-optical network with post-selection:\n1) PDC pair-source S supplies the teleportation SWAP ancilla (two photons).\n2) Heralded gain block G (a second PDC source, pump amplitude set so gain g=2) is inserted in one ancilla arm of the SWAP Bell measurement.\n3) A beam splitter coupling to a vacuum mode implements an effective loss of factor 1/g=\u00bd in the other ancilla arm.\n4) Four photon-number-resolving detectors monitor the two ancilla outputs of G and the two outputs of the loss-BS, plus the two teleported qubit outputs. A specific four-click pattern post-selects U(2).\n5) E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge in the PT-symmetric SWAP-like mapping above.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"PT-symmetric, non-Hermitian two-qubit SWAP gate U(g=2) on two emitter qubits\",\n  \"foldername\": \"PTSwap_g2\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,                          # Researcher: Here is a new Pytheus target\u2014a gain-assisted \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d entanglement-swapping network that implements quantum network coding for two crossing teleportation channels between four nodes:\n\n1) Setup and Goal  \nWe label four single-photon-emitter qubits:  \n  \u2022 Sender A (node 0) holds qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080, Sender B (node 1) holds qubit |\u03d5\u27e9\u2081.  \n  \u2022 Receiver C (node 2) must end up with |\u03c8\u27e9, Receiver D (node 3) with |\u03d5\u27e9.  \nWe wish to cross the two teleportation channels (A\u2192D and B\u2192C) in one static linear-optics circuit, consuming only two Bell-pair ancilla sources plus two heralded PDC gain blocks\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding.\n\n2) Resources  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0,1] prepare input qubits.  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S_A and S_B (standard PDC) create ancilla entangled photon pairs for the A\u2192mid and B\u2192mid teleportations.  \n  \u2022 Two additional heralded PDC sources G_A and G_B act as \u201cgain boosters,\u201d i.e. lasing blocks, each inserted into one arm of its respective Bell-measurement interferometer to amplify the two-photon interference terms and elevate success probabilities.  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) implements the \u201cbutterfly\u201d fan-in: it mixes the four ancilla modes from S_A,S_B,G_A,G_B according to the classical butterfly code pattern, then fans\u2010out to perform the two Bell-measurements simultaneously.  \n  \u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald the simultaneous success of both teleportation channels.  \n  \u2022 The output matter qubits at nodes 2 and 3 (receivers C and D) receive the teleported states via post-selection\u2014they emerge in |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 and |\u03d5\u27e9\u2083.\n\n3) Visualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2510                 \u250c\u2500\u2500[Receiver D_out node 3]  \n                 \u251c\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1_A\u2500\u2500[G_A]\u2500\u253c\u2500Network-coded mixer\u2500ancilla detectors (4)  \n emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2518                 \u2514\u2500\u2500[Receiver C_out node 2]  \n      Bell\u2010pair S_A feeds \ud835\udcd1_A inputs (E\u2080\u2019s photon + ancilla)  \n      Bell\u2010pair S_B feeds \ud835\udcd1_B inputs (E\u2081\u2019s photon + ancilla)  \n      G_A,G_B (gain boosters) each sit in one arm of \ud835\udcd1_A,\ud835\udcd1_B respectively  \n      The 4 ancilla outputs are mixed in a 4-port \u201cbutterfly\u201d interferometer and detected.\n\n4) Pytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted quantum butterfly: network-coded entanglement swap for A\u2192D, B\u2192C\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"QuantumButterflyCAT\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                                # four ancilla detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                         # basis mapping for the two-qubit teleportation  \n    \"0000\",  # |\u03c8,\u03d5> = |00> \u2192 |00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01> \u2192 swapped to node 2  \n    \"1001\",  # |10> \u2192 swapped to node 3  \n    \"1111\"   # |11> \u2192 |11>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],                    # A and B qubits  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\n5) Why It\u2019s Novel & Powerful  \n  \u2022 This is the first static linear-optical demonstration of quantum network coding for two crossing teleportation channels\u2014realizing the \u201cbutterfly\u201d network in the quantum domain.  \n  \u2022 Heralded PDC gain blocks (G_A,G_B) serve as photonic \u201clasing\u201d amplifiers, boosting both teleportation-swap success rates while reducing the required ancilla resources compared to two independent swaps.  \n  \u2022 Fully implementable by Pytheus: only uses single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for both Bell resources and gain), static beam splitters/phase shifters, and post-selecting photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n  \u2022 Generalizable: one can extend to N\u00d7N network-coded teleportation architectures, explore the interplay of gain thresholds and network capacity, or merge with indefinite-order channel routing to open a whole class of quantum network primitives at the interface of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too their pump amplitudes set the effective gain.  \n\u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla arms post-select successful two-hop teleportation.  \n\u2022 By tuning pump strength of G\u2081,G\u2082, the probability that both swaps succeed exhibits a sharp threshold\u2014a lasing-like percolation phase transition in network reachability.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Two-hop teleportation with heralded PDC gain \u2013 percolation threshold demo\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTeleportChain\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                      # four ancilla detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                # teleportation map: |\u03c8>\u2080\u2192|\u03c8>\u2083  \n    \"00\",  # |0>\u2192|0>  \n    \"11\"   # |1>\u2192|1>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,3],          # emitter A (0) and emitter B (3)  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],         # allow all pair-source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:  \n1. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching.
