LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:  \nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to merge \u201clasing behavior\u201d (heralded PDC gain blocks) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single-photon emitters) in a Pytheus-compatible network transformation:  \n  a) A controlled superposition of two entanglement-swapping orders (a quantum SWITCH) that routes entanglement between two emitter-qubits via two distinct swap channels, with PDC gain blocks acting as coherent \u201cswitches.\u201d  \n  b) A heralded, gain-boosted teleportation of a matter qubit through a cascade of intermediate emitter nodes, where each hop uses a PDC \u201clasing\u201d stage to probabilistically amplify the Bell-measurement.  \n  c) A multi-user entanglement multiplexer: three emitter nodes share a single multimode photonic bus, and PDC gain blocks selectively amplify only one emitter\u2019s photons at a time, implementing a switchable entanglement fan-out.  \nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & Pytheus feasibility:  \n  a) The superposed-order swap (quantum SWITCH) is novel\u2014no Pytheus design has ever realized indefinite causal order in a swapping network. It uses only probabilistic pair sources (for the two swap channels and gain switches), single_emitters, linear-optics interferometers, and heralding detectors.  \n  b) The cascaded teleportation is too similar to sequential swap/distillation experiments already explored.  \n  c) The entanglement multiplexer reduces to state routing rather than a fundamentally new superposed process.  \nStep 3: Choose idea (a) \u2013 the \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH for entanglement swapping.\u201d  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a coherent superposition of two distinct entanglement-swapping operations on matter qubits\u2014a demonstration of indefinite causal order in a quantum network\u2014using only linear optics, heralded PDC gain blocks, and single-photon emitters. No prior Pytheus experiment has explored such a superposed network transformation.  \nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in the Pytheus framework since it requires:  \n  \u2022 single_emitters for the two matter-qubit inputs,  \n  \u2022 four PDC pair-sources (two for the swap channels, two as heralded gain/switch blocks),  \n  \u2022 a static linear-optical interferometer to coherently split and recombine the ancilla photon through the two swap routes, and  \n  \u2022 post-selection on heralding detectors to project onto the coherent superposition of swap outcomes.  \nNo cavities, no active feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-based quantum SWITCH\u201d that coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping channels between two single-photon-emitter qubits, harnessing lasing-like PDC gain blocks as quantum-controlled switches:\n\nDescription:  \nWe have two matter qubits stored in single_emitters E\u2080 and E\u2081. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # ancilla detectors on G\u1d64/G\u2097 outputs  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [          # superposed swap: |\u03c8,\u03d5> \u2192 (|\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2081 + |\u03a6\u207a>_swap\u2082)\u2297\u2026  \n    \"0000\",  \n    \"0110\",  \n    \"1001\",  \n    \"1111\"  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],    # E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is exciting and generalizable:  \n\u2022 It is the first photonic\u2013matter demonstration of a quantum-SWITCH primitive for entanglement swapping\u2014realizing indefinite causal order in a quantum network.  \n\u2022 The heralded PDC gain blocks serve double duty: they both amplify the two-photon interference (lasing analogy) and coherently switch between two network channels.  \n\u2022 By adding more swap channels and gain blocks, one can build higher-dimensional quantum SWITCH networks (superpositions of multiple swap orders), or explore programmable network architectures that exploit superposed routing.  \n\u2022 This family of experiments opens a new domain at the interface of quantum networks, indefinite causal order, and nonlinear optics\u2013inspired \u201clasing\u201d primitives\u2014without ever leaving the realm of static linear\u2010optical circuits and post\u2010selection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme reproduces the previously proposed entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch (superposed swap orders) from the ensemble, and the PDC gain blocks only serve to boost amplitudes rather than implement a new primitive. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:  \nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201clasing behavior\u201d (heralded PDC gain) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single\u2010photon emitter qubits) in a network transformation:  \n  a) A heralded, gain-enhanced Fredkin (CSWAP) gate on three emitter qubits: teleport\u2010based controlled\u2010swap boosted by PDC gain blocks.  \n  b) A multi-path entanglement\u2010percolation router where PDC gain stages induce a threshold behavior in which distant emitter nodes become entangled only above a pump amplitude.  \n  c) A superposed-order quantum SWITCH of two distinct three-node repeater segments, with gain blocks as quantum switches.  \n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:  \n  a) The Fredkin/CSWAP gate has not yet been implemented in Pytheus (they have CNOT, Toffoli, SWAP, but not CSWAP). Adding heralded PDC gain blocks is a new twist. All required elements\u2014single_emitters, PDC pair sources, beam splitters, detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  b) The percolation idea is appealing but Pytheus cannot easily capture an amplitude\u2010driven phase transition as a single static target.  \n  c) The superposed repeater switch is conceptually nice but risks collapsing to the previously critiqued SWITCH proposals.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea (a): the gain-enhanced heralded Fredkin gate.  \n\nStep 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus experiment realizes a three\u2010qubit CSWAP on matter qubits. Introducing heralded PDC blocks as \u201clasing gain\u201d to amplify the two teleportation branches of the swap is entirely new\u2014a nontrivial network transformation combining teleportation\u2010based gates with gain\u2010mediated success boosting.  \n\nStep 5: Feasibility: Uses only static linear optics, probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (for Bell resources and gain stages), single_emitters for the three matter\u2010qubit inputs, and post-selection via photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. No cavities, no feedback\u2014fully compatible with Pytheus.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a new Pytheus target: a heralded, gain-enhanced Fredkin (CSWAP) gate acting on three single-photon\u2013emitter qubits (indices 0,1,2), combining \u201clasing\u201d PDC gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling:\n\n1) Goal: Implement the three-qubit CSWAP (Fredkin) unitary  \n   \u2022 Control qubit C\u2009=\u2009E\u2080; targets T\u2081\u2009=\u2009E\u2081, T\u2082\u2009=\u2009E\u2082  \n   \u2022 If\u2009C=|0\u27e9, do nothing: |0,xy\u27e9\u2192|0,xy\u27e9 for x,y\u2208{0,1}  \n   \u2022 If\u2009C=|1\u27e9, swap targets: |1,xy\u27e9\u2192|1,yx\u27e9  \n\n2) Strategy: Teleport-based controlled-swap  \n   \u2022 Two Bell\u2010pair sources S\u2081 (for T\u2081) and S\u2082 (for T\u2082) supply entanglement resources.  \n   \u2022 Two heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 are inserted in one arm of the Bell analyzers for S\u2081 and S\u2082, respectively. Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers). Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Idea (1) is the most novel: no Pytheus design yet realizes a continuously tunable two\u2010qubit gate (\u221aSWAP) on emitter qubits, nor uses PDC gain to set the interaction angle.  \nStep 3: Pick idea (1).  \nStep 4: This is novel because it turns the teleportation\u2010based SWAP gate into a fully tunable partial\u2010SWAP family by embedding heralded PDC amplifiers as \u201clasing\u201d elements\u2014creating a continuous SU(2) two\u2010qubit interaction on matter qubits that has never been implemented in Pytheus.  \nStep 5: It is feasible with Pytheus: uses two PDC sources for Bell resources, two more for heralded gain, single_emitters for the qubits, static beam splitters/phase shifters, and heralding detectors. No cavities or feedback are required.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP (partial\u2010swap) gate between two single\u2010photon\u2013emitter qubits, merging lasing\u2010style gain blocks with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a network transformation:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to implement the two\u2010qubit unitary\n\n\u2003U(\u03b8)=|00\u27e9\u27e800|+|11\u27e9\u27e811|+cos\u03b8(|01\u27e9\u27e801|+|10\u27e9\u27e810|)+i\u2009sin\u03b8(|01\u27e9\u27e810|+|10\u27e9\u27e801|)\n\non emitter qubits E\u2080,E\u2081. Here \u03b8\u2208[0,\u03c0/2] is set by the pump strength of two heralded PDC gain blocks (\u201cG\u2081,G\u2082\u201d), realizing a continuous partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP at \u03b8=\u03c0/4).\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081 \u2500 [G\u2081] \u2500\u2510 \u2571  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518               \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u253c\u2500  detectors herald \u03b8  \n                                 \u2502   \u2572\u2514\u2500\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2510              \u2502  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082 \u2500 [G\u2082]\u2500\u2518  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081,S\u2082: two PDC sources supply the entangled ancilla photons for teleportation\u2010based SWAP.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082: Bell analyzers mix E\u2080/E\u2081 photons with their ancilla.  \n\u2022 G\u2081,G\u2082: additional PDC sources placed in one arm of each Bell analyzer act as heralded gain (lasing) blocks; their pump amplitudes tune \u03b8.  \n\u2022 A final 50/50 BS recombines the two gain-ancilla outputs. Four number-resolving detectors project onto the correct joint herald pattern, post-selecting U(\u03b8) on (E\u2080,E\u2081).  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded, gain\u2010tunable \u221aSWAP gate between two single\u2010photon emitters\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTunableSqrtSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # mapping the four logical inputs+outputs  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192cos\u03b8|01>+i\u2009sin\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192i\u2009sin\u03b8|01>+cos\u03b8|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|11>  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # nodes E\u2080 and E\u2081  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey points and generalizations:  \n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1] are the matter\u2010qubit inputs.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources (S\u2081,S\u2082) for Bell resources; two more (G\u2081,G\u2082) as heralded gain blocks whose pump amplitude sets \u03b8 (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement a teleportation\u2010based \u221aSWAP gate on E\u2080,E\u2081\u2014realizing a continuous family of entangling gates rather than a fixed SWAP.  \n\u2022 By sweeping the pump of G\u2081,G\u2082, one explores the transition from identity (\u03b8=0) to full SWAP (\u03b8=\u03c0/2), exhibiting how gain reveals a continuous SU(2) two\u2010qubit interaction in a measurement\u2010based network.  \n\u2022 This building block can be extended to arbitrary two\u2010qubit gates (e.g. controlled\u2010\u221aSWAP, \u221aFredkin) with embedded gain, opening a rich class of \u201cgain\u2010driven\u201d quantum\u2010network primitives at the intersection of lasing physics and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme replicates the known heralded partial-SWAP (\u221aSWAP) gate, merely adding heralded PDC amplifiers as performance enhancers. It\u2019s a pure network transformation (measurement).  \n  b) The parity\u2010check is interesting but is essentially a two\u2010qubit Bell measurement variant already covered by gain\u2010boosted Bell analyzers.  \n  c) The programmable router is similar to earlier multi\u2010node swap proposals and risks falling back on state generation or performance tweaks.  \n\nStep 3: Pick (a): the a multiport interferometer, we boost the higher\u2010order interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d) and can in principle resolve all eight GHZ states.\n\nSetup sketch the first design of a three\u2010qubit GHZ analyzer in linear\u2010optical quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Heralded PDC gain blocks serve as \u201clasing\u201d amplifiers of higher\u2010order LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:  \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to fuse heralded PDC \u201clasing\u201d gain with single-photon emitter (\u201cstrong light\u2013matter\u201d) qubits in a genuine network measurement or gate (no state generation):  \n  1) A near-deterministic, non-demolition GHZ-parity check (three-qubit projective measurement) that uses two heralded PDC gain blocks to boost the three-photon interference, projecting three matter qubits onto their GHZ\u00b1 subspace without destroying them.  \n  2) A gain-controlled, teleportation-based XX\u2010gate (exp(i\u03c6\u2009X\u2297X)) between two matter qubits, where \u03c6 is tunable by PDC pump amplitude.  \n  3) A \u201cquantum-catalytic repeater\u201d node that entangles two distant qubits using a third catalyst qubit and PDC gain blocks, returning the catalyst to its original state.  \nStep 2: Novelty & feasibility:  \n  1) The non-demolition GHZ-parity check is genuinely new to Pytheus: no existing network implements a three-qubit projector on matter qubits or uses PDC gain to exceed LOQC success bounds. It uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for the GHZ ancilla and gain blocks), beam splitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus capabilities.  \n  2) The XX-gate is interesting but similar in spirit to the \u221aSWAP/CZ families already explored.  \n  3) The catalytic repeater is conceptually neat but would reduce to a specialized form of entanglement-swapping plus ancilla recovery, which Pytheus could already approximate.  \nStep 3: Select idea (1): the non-demolition, gain-assisted three-qubit GHZ-parity check.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it elevates measurement from two-qubit Bell checks to a true three-qubit GHZ parity projector on matter qubits\u2014an entirely new network primitive\u2014and it employs heralded PDC amplifiers to push the success probability arbitrarily close to unity, surpassing all known LOQC bounds.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework since it uses exactly the elements Pytheus supports\u2014single_photon_emitters, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without any cavities, dynamic feedback, or forbidden state-generation targets.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014a near-deterministic, non-demolition GHZ-parity check on three single-photon-emitter qubits, combining lasing-style heralded PDC gain with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a novel quantum-network measurement primitive:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three matter qubits encoded in single_emitters E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2). Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. Four photon-number-resolving detectors monitor the ancilla outputs.  \n\u2022 A specific click pattern on these detectors heralds P_GHZ=+1 (even GHZ parity); the complementary pattern heralds P_GHZ=\u22121.  \n\u2022 Crucially, the matter qubits themselves are left intact\u2014projected non-destructively into the corresponding GHZ parity subspace\u2014enabling mid-circuit syndrome extraction or adaptive network protocols.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Non-demolition, gain-assisted GHZ-parity check for three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainGHZParity\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 40,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Four distinct 4-click patterns  \n    \"2000\",  # It remains a measurement\u2010and\u2010post\u2010select network transformation, uses only single_emitters, PDC pair sources (for both Bell resources and \u201cgain boosters\u201d), linear optics, and photon\u2010number\u2013resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  \u2022 Ideas 2 and 3 either collapse to GHZ/Bell analyzers or to continuous\u2010parameter gates already explored.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea 1: the gain\u2010assisted network\u2010coded entanglement\u2010swap (\u201cquantum butterfly\u201d).  \nStep 4: Novelty: It implements the quantum analogue of the classical butterfly network code\u2014crossing two qubit\u2010teleportation channels through a single static linear\u2010optical circuit\u2014and uses heralded PDC gain blocks to boost both swaps simultaneously while consuming fewer ancillas than two independent swap circuits. No prior Pytheus experiment has realized network coding of quantum flows.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Uses only single_emitters for the two sender qubits, two PDC sources for Bell\u2010pair ancillas, two extra PDC \u201cgain\u201d sources inserted into the ancilla arms to amplify the two\u2010photon interference of each swap channel, static beam splitters and phase shifters for the butterfly nodes:\n\n1) Setup and Goal  \nWe label four single-photon-emitter qubits:  \n  \u2022 Sender A (node 0) holds qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080, Sender B (node 1) holds qubit |\u03d5\u27e9\u2081.  \n  \u2022 G_A and G_B act as \u201cgain boosters,\u201d i.e. lasing blocks, each inserted into one arm of its respective Bell-measurement interferometer to amplify the two-photon interference terms and elevate success probabilities.  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) implements the \u201cbutterfly\u201d fan-in: it mixes the four ancilla modes from S_A,S_B,G_A,G_B herald the simultaneous success of both teleportation channels.  \n  \u2022 The output matter qubits at nodes 2 and 3 (receivers C and D) receive the teleported states via post-selection\u2014they emerge in |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 and |\u03d5\u27e9\u2083.\n\n3) Visualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2510                 \u250c\u2500\u2500[Receiver D_out node 3]  \n This goes beyond simple teleportation or state generation, uses only static linear optics, PDC pair sources, single_emitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, and opens a family of nested, gain-tunable distillation protocols.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a target for Pytheus\u2014a gain-assisted entanglement-distillation module between two distant single-photon\u2013emitter qubits:\n\n1) Task  \nWe have two initial noisy Bell pairs shared between matter qubit nodes A and B:  \n  \u2022 A holds emitters E\u2080 and E\u2082 (nodes 0,2).  \n  \u2022 B holds emitters E\u2081 and E\u2083 (nodes 1,3).  \nGoal: distill a single, higher-fidelity Bell pair between E\u2080 and E\u2081 by consuming the second pair (E\u2082\u2013E\u2083) in a gain-enhanced Bell measurement.\n\n2) Resources  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0,1,2,3] for E\u2080,E\u2081,E\u2082,E\u2083.  \n  \u2022 Two PDC pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082 generate the noisy Bell pairs between (E\u2080\u2013E\u2081) and (E\u2082\u2013E\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081 and G\u2082 serve as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers, inserted into the two ancilla arms of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer on E\u2082\u2013E\u2083. Their pump amplitudes tune the effective gain (lasing analogue).  \n  \u2022 A linear-optical Bell\u2010analyzer \ud835\udcd1 mixes photons from E\u2082 and E\u2083 with one photon each from G\u2081 and G\u2082.  \n  \u2022 Four number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald a successful projection onto the \u201ceven\u201d Bell subspace of E\u2082\u2013E\u2083, which\u2014upon post-selection\u2014projects E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 onto a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state.  \n\n3) Network Sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2082]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                      \n                  \u251c\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n  Bell source S\u2082\u2500\u2518                \u251c\u2500 detectors for distillation herald  \n                                  \u2514\u2500\u2500[G\u2082]  \n emitters: [E\u2083]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\nMeanwhile E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 remain untouched until herald fires; then E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 collapse into the distilled Bell pair.\n\n4) Pytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted distillation node for two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainDistillNode\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                       # four detectors on the distillation Bell\u2010analyzer  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [                 # heralding patterns corresponding to the <\u03a6+| projection on E\u2082\u2013E\u2083  \n    \"2000\",  # two photons in detector0  \n    \"0200\",  \n    \"0020\",  \n    \"0002\"  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [2,3],           # E\u2082 and E\u2083 are measured  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\n5) Why It\u2019s Novel & Generalizable  \n  \u2022 First-ever heralded, gain-boosted entanglement distillation node in photonic quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 PDC gain blocks G\u2081,G\u2082 implement \u201clasing behavior,\u201d amplifying constructive interference in the distillation measurement and boosting both success probability and output fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Only static linear optics, probabilistic PDC sources, single_emitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n  \u2022 Can be nested: multiple such nodes chained or concatenated yield multi-round distillation protocols, tunable by gain pump strengths\u2014exploring threshold effects and percolation of high-fidelity links in repeater networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your proposal duplicates the known one\u2010step distillation/repeater module (\u201cSwap\u2013and\u2013Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\u201d) and simply adds PDC gain stages to improve success probability. To reach true novelty, you must introduce a fundamentally new transformation\u2014e.g. a non-Hermitian purification operator, indefinite-order distillation superposition, or a topology-protected multi\u2010pair distillation protocol\u2014not just a performance enhancement of an existing LOQC purification circuit.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:  \nWe need a genuinely new network transformation\u2014no pure state generation\u2014combining heralded PDC \u201clasing\u201d gain with abstract single\u2010photon emitter qubits. A non\u2010unitary, heralded amplitude filter (Kraus operator) on two matter qubits that boosts one joint basis amplitude implements a new primitive (\u201cquantum gain filter\u201d) for networked qubits. This goes beyond boosting success rates for known gates; it realizes a tunable, non\u2010Hermitian two\u2010qubit map. It uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for both Bell resources and gain), static linear optics, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully Pytheus\u2010compatible.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain\u2010assisted non\u2010unitary \u201cquantum gain filter\u201d on two single\u2010photon\u2013emitter qubits, combining lasing\u2010style PDC amplifiers and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a new network transformation:\n\nDescription:  \nWe denote two abstract qubits in single_emitters E\u2080 (node 0) and E\u2081 (node 1). We wish to implement the probabilistic Kraus map K:  \n\u2003|00\u27e9\u2192|00\u27e9,\u2003|01\u27e9\u2192|01\u27e9,\u2003|10\u27e9\u2192|10\u27e9,\u2003|11\u27e9\u2192g\u2009|11\u27e9  \n(with normalization and post\u2010selection), for a chosen gain factor g>1 (e.g. g=2). This \u201cquantum gain filter\u201d amplifies the |11\u27e9 component only, a non\u2010unitary, non\u2010Hermitian network operation useful for entanglement distillation, error filtering, and novel protocol design.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):  \n emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500\u2500[E\u2080_out]  \n                  \u251c\u2500Teleportation\u2013based filter\u2500\u252c\u2500[matched\u2010loss BS]\u2500\u2510  \nBell\u2010pair S \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                            \u2502                 \u2502  \n                                              \u251c\u2500[PDC gain G]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524 ancilla detectors  \nemitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2510                            \u2502                 \u2502  \n                \u251c\u2500Teleportation branch\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                 \u2514\u2500\u2500[E\u2081_out]  \nmatched\u2010loss BS coupled to vacuum implements 1/g attenuation in the non\u2010gain arm.  \nG is a heralded PDC source (pump sets g), inserted in the gain arm of the filter circuit.  \nFour photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald successful K.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Heralded quantum gain filter for two emitter qubits (g=2)\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"QuantumGainFilter\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 20,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"01\",\"10\",\"11\"],  \n  \"amplitudes\":   [1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 2.0],  # implement K|ij> = amplitude\u00d7|ij>  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],         # input qubits at nodes 0 and 1  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nWhy this is new & powerful:  \n\u2022 Implements a non\u2010unitary, tunable two\u2010qubit Kraus operation\u2014\u201cquantum gain filter\u201d\u2014never before designed in Pytheus.  \n\u2022 Fuses heralded PDC gain (\u201clasing\u201d) and abstract single_emitters (\u201cstrong light\u2013matter\u201d) in one network element.  \n\u2022 Static linear optics + post\u2010selection only\u2014no cavities, no feedback.  \n\u2022 Generalizes to arbitrary gain profiles or multi\u2010basis filters, enabling new protocols for entanglement distillation, error mitigation, and non\u2010Hermitian quantum-network elements."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. This design constitutes the first demonstration of on\u2010chip, mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed entanglement purification in three dimensions, establishing a vital primitive for scalable, multi\u2010stage high\u2010dimensional quantum networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Spatial-Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping on a Nanoscale Waveguide Chip\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fully passive on-chip architecture for entanglement swapping in which k probabilistic photon-pair sources on each link (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are coherently funneled through fixed multiport coupler trees in a nanoscale waveguide to boost the heralded Bell-swap success probability without any active switching or feedback. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus to design an \u201camplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate\u201d between two single\u2010photon emitters, combining lasing\u2010style gain (via extra PDC sources) and strong light\u2013matter coupling (abstract single_emitters) in a heralded teleportation network.\n\nExplanation:  \nWe want to realize a post\u2010selected SWAP gate on two emitter\u2010qubits E_A and E_B by teleporting E_A\u2192E_B and E_B\u2192E_A simultaneously, but boosted by \u201cgain\u201d PDC sources that amplify the Bell\u2010measurement success probability (mimicking lasing behavior).  \n\n1) Single\u2010photon emitters [0] and [1] prepare the two arbitrary input qubits (strong light\u2013matter coupling nodes).  \n2) Two PDC sources (S1, S2) generate the Bell pairs needed for teleportation.  \n3) Two additional PDC sources (G1, G2) act as heralded gain blocks: each is placed in one arm of the Bell\u2010measurement interferometer to probabilistically amplify the two\u2010photon interference terms, thereby increasing the teleportation success amplitude.  \n4) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the Bell\u2010measurement on the four photonic modes (two from emitters + two from S1,S2), interleaved with gain blocks G1,G2.  \n5) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancillary modes; successful SWAP is post\u2010selected on a specific four\u2010click pattern.  \n6) Outputs at two designated detectors carry the teleported states to E_B and E_A respectively (abstractly the outputs \u201cland\u201d back on the matter nodes).\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \nemitters:  [Emitter 0] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2510                     \u250c\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_B]  \n                        \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G1]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510  detectors         \nemitters:  [Emitter 1] \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2518               \u2502  \u2514\u2500[G2]\u2500(Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2014\u2510  \n                                         \u2502                 \u2514\u2014\u2014 [Detected \u2192 E_A]  \nBell-sources S1,S2 feed the middle of each Bell circuit; G1,G2 (gain PDCs) are inserted in the two ancilla arms.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:  \n{  \n  \"description\": \"Amplified teleportation\u2013based SWAP gate between two single-photon emitters\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainTeleportSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n emitters  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}  \n\nKey points:  \n- single_emitters index 0 and 1 are the two matter qubits\u2019 inputs.  \n- four ancilla detectors herald the desired SWAP outcome.  \n- PDC sources used both for Bell resources (S1,S2) and gain blocks (G1,G2).  \n- Linear optics only\u2014no cavities or feedback.  \n\nThis network can be generalized to teleportation\u2010based two\u2010qubit gates with adjustable gain stages, or cascaded to build larger repeaters and multi\u2010node SWAP networks, illustrating a whole family of experiments at the interplay of lasing\u2010like gain and strong light\u2013matter coupling.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The core proposal is simply a teleportation\u2010based SWAP (two simultaneous teleportations) onto matter qubits\u2014essentially the same target as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Programmable Teleportation of CNOT and SWAP Gates onto Two Neutral-Atom Qubits\u201d\u2014with the only twist being insertion of PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to boost success probability.  While heralded amplification gadgets exist, tacking them onto a standard LOQC teleportation circuit does not introduce a fundamentally new network primitive or resource\u2014merely a performance enhancement.  This falls short of a genuinely novel quantum-optical target worthy of PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme reduces to two concurrent teleportations (SWAP) on matter qubits\u2014already realized virtually identically (see the ensemble\u2019s atomic\u2010qubit SWAP teleportation)\u2014and the addition of heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d stages merely improves success rate rather than enacting a new transformation or exhibiting new physics. To be novel, propose either a qualitatively new routing or gate primitive (beyond two\u2010qubit SWAP) or exploit the gain blocks in a way that fundamentally alters the network\u2019s causal or entanglement structure rather than just boosting amplitudes.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is an experimental target for Pytheus\u2014a heralded, gain-enhanced teleportation-based CZ gate between two single-photon-emitter qubits:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe wish to perform a controlled-phase (CZ) gate on two abstract qubits stored in single-photon emitters E0 (control) and E1 (target). Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs; a particular four-click pattern heralds successful CZ. E0_out and E1_out carry the phase-flipped joint state CZ|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 back onto the emitters.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-enhanced heralded CZ gate between two single-photon-emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainCZGate\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # CZ truth\u2010table mapping  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0101\",  # |01>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1010\",  # |10>\u2192|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192\u2212|11>  (phase flip encoded by global sign)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # E0 and E1 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey features and generalizations:  \n- single_emitters index 0,1 are the two matter qubits.  \n- Two PDC sources S\u2081,S\u2082 supply Bell resources; We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Here \u03b8\u2208[0,\u03c0/2] is set by the pump strength of two heralded PDC gain blocks (\u201cG\u2081,G\u2082\u201d), realizing a continuous partial\u2010SWAP (\u221aSWAP at \u03b8=\u03c0/4).\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081 \u2500 [G\u2081] \u2500\u2510 \u2571  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2081\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518               \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u253c\u2500  detectors herald \u03b8  \n                                 \u2502   \u2572\u2514\u2500\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2510              \u2502  \n                 \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2082 \u2500 [G\u2082]\u2500\u2518  \nBell\u2010pair S\u2082\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n\u2022 S\u2081,S\u2082: two PDC sources supply the entangled ancilla photons for teleportation\u2010based SWAP.  \n\u2022 \ud835\udcd1\u2081,\ud835\udcd1\u2082: Bell analyzers mix E\u2080/E\u2081 photons with their ancilla.  \n\u2022 G\u2081,G\u2082: additional PDC sources placed in one arm of each Bell analyzer act as heralded gain (lasing) blocks; their pump amplitudes tune \u03b8.  \n\u2022 A final 50/50 BS recombines the two gain-ancilla outputs. Researcher: Here is a new Pytheus target\u2014a gain-assisted \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d entanglement-swapping network that implements quantum network coding for two crossing teleportation channels between four nodes:\n\n1) Setup and Goal  \nWe label four single-photon-emitter qubits:  \n  \u2022 Sender A (node 0) holds qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080, Sender B (node 1) holds qubit |\u03d5\u27e9\u2081.  \n  \u2022 Receiver C (node 2) must end up with |\u03c8\u27e9, Receiver D (node 3) with |\u03d5\u27e9.  \nWe wish to cross the two teleportation channels (A\u2192D and B\u2192C) in one static linear-optics circuit, consuming only two Bell-pair ancilla sources plus two heralded PDC gain blocks\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding.\n\n2) Resources  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0,1] prepare input qubits.  \n  \u2022 Bell-pair sources S_A and S_B (standard PDC) create ancilla entangled photon pairs for the A\u2192mid and B\u2192mid teleportations.  \n  \u2022 Two additional heralded PDC sources G_A and G_B act as \u201cgain boosters,\u201d i.e. lasing blocks, each inserted into one arm of its respective Bell-measurement interferometer to amplify the two-photon interference terms and elevate success probabilities.  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) implements the \u201cbutterfly\u201d fan-in: it mixes the four ancilla modes from S_A,S_B,G_A,G_B according to the classical butterfly code pattern, then fans\u2010out to perform the two Bell-measurements simultaneously.  \n  \u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla outputs herald the simultaneous success of both teleportation channels.  \n  \u2022 The output matter qubits at nodes 2 and 3 (receivers C and D) receive the teleported states via post-selection\u2014they emerge in |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 and |\u03d5\u27e9\u2083.\n\n3) Visualization (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2510 ancilla outputs are mixed in a 4-port \u201cbutterfly\u201d interferometer and detected.\n\n4) Pytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted quantum butterfly: network-coded For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Our goal is a linear\u2010optical circuit that can unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of these qubits with success probability >50%, by incorporating two additional PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d amplifiers in the ancilla arms of the Bell analyzer.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510                   \u250c\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n                             \u251c\u2500\u2500Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2500\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2524  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081]\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 [Detector pattern \u2192 Bell outcome]  \n             \u2191                  \n         Source S\u2090 (Bell resource)  \n  \n  And symmetrically a second Bell analyzer \ud835\udcd1\u2082 fed by Source S_b and Gain block G\u2082, interleaved by a small multiport interferometer that mixes the four modes.\n\n\u2022 S\u2090,S_b are two standard PDC pair sources generating the entangled ancilla photons for the two halves of the Bell analyzer.  \n\u2022 G\u2081 and G\u2082 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) placed in one arm of each Bell measurement. Specific click patterns unambiguously identify each Bell state. Because of the embedded gain blocks, the success probability can in principle exceed 50% (approaching 1 in the high-pump limit), thereby overcoming the standard LOQC bound.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-assisted Bell-state analyzer for two single-photon\u2013emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainBellAnalyzer\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"likelihood\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # It uses only single_emitters, probabilistic pair sources (for the GHZ ancilla and gain blocks), beam splitters, and detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus capabilities.  \n  2) The XX-gate is interesting but similar in spirit to the \u221aSWAP/CZ families already explored.  \n  3) The catalytic repeater is conceptually neat but would reduce to a specialized form of entanglement-swapping plus ancilla recovery, which Pytheus could already approximate.  \nStep 3: Select idea (1): the non-demolition, gain-assisted three-qubit GHZ-parity check.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it elevates measurement from two-qubit Bell checks to a true three-qubit GHZ parity projector on matter qubits\u2014an entirely new network primitive\u2014and it employs heralded PDC amplifiers to push the success probability arbitrarily close to unity, surpassing all known LOQC bounds.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework since it uses exactly the elements Pytheus supports\u2014single_photon_emitters, probabilistic photon-pair sources, static linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without any cavities, dynamic feedback, or forbidden state-generation targets.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014a near-deterministic, non-demolition GHZ-parity check on three single-photon-emitter qubits, combining lasing-style heralded PDC gain with strong light\u2013matter coupling in a novel quantum-network measurement primitive:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three matter qubits encoded in single_emitters E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2). Our goal is to implement a projective measurement of the three-qubit GHZ parity operator  \n\u2003P_GHZ = |000\u27e9\u27e8000| + |111\u27e9\u27e8111| \u2013 (|001\u27e9\u27e8001|+\u2026+|110\u27e9\u27e8110|)  \nin a non-demolition fashion: the input qubits emerge in the P_GHZ=+1 subspace if they began there, or in the \u20131 subspace if so, and remain available for further processing.\n\nNetwork sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters: [E\u2080] \u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u250c\u2500 qubits out (still on 0,1,2)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 GHZ-swap\u2010network \ud835\udcd6 \u2500[BS]\u2500\u2500  \n emitters: [E\u2081] \u2500\u2500\u2524                     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detections  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2500 Bell-pair S\u2090 \u2192 \u25a0 \u2192 [G\u2081]  \n emitters: [E\u2082] \u2500\u2500\u2518                          \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\n\n\u2022 single_emitters [0,1,2] supply the three unknown qubit photons to the GHZ-analyzer \ud835\udcd6.  \n\u2022 Two PDC sources S\u2090,S_b generate ancilla photons for the GHZ parity measurement.  \n\u2022 Two additional PDC sources G\u2081,G\u2082 act as heralded gain blocks inserted into the ancilla arms of \ud835\udcd6, boosting the three-photon interference amplitudes (\u201clasing behavior\u201d).  \n\u2022 A static linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters/phases) mixes all five photons. We wish, in a single static linear\u2010optics circuit, to teleport A\u2192B, B\u2192C and C\u2192A simultaneously in a fully directional \u201ccirculator\u201d primitive.  Standard LOQC teleportation is bidirectional and one\u2010hop; here we entwine three Bell\u2010swap channels in a ring and use heralded PDC gain blocks to break reciprocity and boost interference, achieving near\u2010deterministic three\u2010way circulation.\n\n1) Resources  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [0]=A, [1]=B, [2]=C  \n \u2022 Three Bell\u2010pair sources S_AB, S_BC, S_CA (probabilistic PDC) furnish the three teleportation links.  \n \u2022 Three additional PDC sources G_AB, G_BC, G_CA, each inserted in one ancilla arm of its corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, serve as heralded gain blocks (\u201clasing\u201d elements) that amplify the two\u2010photon interference amplitude in the forward direction.  \n \u2022 A static network of beam splitters and phase shifters overlaps the six ancilla modes (one from each Bell source, one from each gain block) in a three\u2010port interferometer that enforces the circulator routing.  \n \u2022 Six number\u2010resolving
