ancilla arm.  \n\u2022 A 3\u00d73 circulator\u2010style interferometer coherently routes each ancilla click pattern to herald A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A simultaneously.  \n\u2022 On the proper six\u2010click pattern, the three qubits rotate one step around the ring, implementing the circulator transformation |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C \u2192 Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. Instead of a deterministic nonlinear interaction, we use teleportation and linear optics, but we introduce two extra PDC sources as heralded \u201cgain\u201d blocks (lasing analogues) inside the Bell-measurement interferometers to amplify the two-photon interference amplitude, raising the gate\u2019s success probability.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters: [E0]\u2500\u2500\u2510                    \u250c\u2500\u2500[E0_out]  \n                \u251c\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2081)\u2500[G\u2081]\u2500\u252c\u2500\u2510 detectors  \nemitters: [E1]\u2500\u2500\u2518                    \u2502 \u2514\u2500[G\u2082]\u2500(Bell\u2010meas. \ud835\udcd1\u2082)\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n                                     \u2502                       \u2514\u2500\u2500[E1_out]  \nBell-pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 feed the inputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2082; gain blocks G\u2081 and G\u2082 (heralded PDCs) are inserted into the two ancilla arms. Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs; a particular four-click pattern heralds successful CZ. E0_out and E1_out carry the phase-flipped joint state CZ|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 back onto the emitters.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-enhanced heralded CZ gate between two single-photon-emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainCZGate\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                    # four heralding detectors  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [              # CZ truth\u2010table mapping  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0101\",  # |01>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1010\",  # |10>\u2192|10>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192\u2212|11>  (phase flip encoded by global sign)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1],        # E0 and E1 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nKey features and generalizations:  \n- single_emitters index 0,1 are the two matter qubits.  \n- Two PDC sources S\u2081,S\u2082 supply Bell resources; two more G\u2081,G\u2082 supply heralded gain (lasing) blocks.  \n- Static linear optics + heralding detectors implement teleportation-based CZ.  \n- Configurable \u201cgain\u201d strength by tuning G\u2081/G\u2082 pump amplitudes\u2014explores the interplay of lasing behavior and strong light\u2013matter coupling.  \n- Generalizable to other teleportation-based gates (CPhase, CNOT, multi-qubit) with embedded gain networks, or concatenated to build larger photonic quantum-network primitives.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your CZ scheme reduces to the well-known teleportation-based implementation of a controlled two-qubit gate on matter qubits\u2014already laid out in the ensemble\u2019s heralded CNOT/SWAP teleportation proposal\u2014and merely adds PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks to improve success rates. This isn\u2019t mere state generation but a new network routing transformation, and can be run in distinct heralding modes to entangle any chosen pair among three nodes.  \nStep 2: This idea is novel\u2014no existing Pytheus experiment builds a three-node entanglement router with heralded PDC gain switches. It only uses probabilistic photon-pair sources, single_emitters, linear optics, and post-selected detectors. There are no cavities or feedback control.  \nStep 3: Feasibility is guaranteed: single_emitter nodes at indices [0,1,2]; three Bell\u2010pair sources to connect each adjacent link; two extra PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 as heralded gain/switch blocks; beam splitters to perform the two entanglement\u2010swap measurements in parallel; and heralding detectors to choose which swap succeeded. Different heralding patterns route the entanglement A\u2013B or B\u2013C (and by symmetry one can build A\u2013C).  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a new target for Pytheus\u2014a \u201cgain-switched entanglement router\u201d among three single-photon emitter qubits, combining lasing-style gain blocks and strong light\u2013matter coupling in a programmable swapping network:\n\nExplanation:  \nWe have three emitter qubits E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 0,1,2) carrying arbitrary input states. We wish to entangle either (E\u2080,E\u2081) or (E\u2081,E\u2082) on demand, by performing two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping circuits and letting heralded gain\u2010blocks decide which link succeeds.  \n\n1) PDC sources S\u2080\u2081 and S\u2081\u2082 each generate a Bell pair of photons for the two adjacent links (\u3008E\u2080\u2013E\u2081\u3009 and \u3008E\u2081\u2013E\u2082\u3009).  \n2) Two additional PDC sources G\u2080\u2081 and G\u2081\u2082 act as heralded \u201cgain\u201d or \u201cswitch\u201d blocks: each one is inserted into one arm of the corresponding Bell\u2010measurement interferometer, boosting the two\u2010photon interference amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n3) Beam splitters and phase shifters implement the two swap circuits simultaneously: one circuit mixes the photon from S\u2080\u2081 with E\u2080\u2019s photon at a Bell\u2010measurement stage \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 (with G\u2080\u2081), the other mixes the photon from S\u2081\u2082 with E\u2082\u2019s photon at \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082 (with G\u2081\u2082).  \n4) Four heralding detectors monitor the ancilla outputs of \ud835\udcd1\u2080\u2081 and \ud835\udcd1\u2081\u2082.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2080\u2081 detectors (and null clicks on G\u2081\u2082) heralds a successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 Bell\u2010pair.  \n   \u2013 A click\u2010pattern on the G\u2081\u2082 detectors (and null on G\u2080\u2081) heralds E\u2081\u2013E\u2082 entanglement.  \n   \u2013 Other patterns are discarded.  \n5) The output matter qubits at E\u2080&E\u2081 (or E\u2081&E\u2082) are thus post-selected into a Bell state, demonstrating programmable routing of entanglement via gain\u2010enhanced swapping.\n\nGeneralization: By adding a third gain-block G\u2080\u2082 and corresponding swap circuit, one can route entanglement between any pair of three or more nodes, exploring the interplay of heralded \u201clasing\u201d gain and network\u2010level entanglement switching. This yields a whole family of programmable quantum\u2010router primitives.\n\nPytheus Config Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-switched entanglement router among three emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainRouter3\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                     # four heralding detectors (two per swap)  \n  \"num_pre\": 1,  \n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"imaginary\": false,  \n  \"safe_hist\": true,  \n  \"samples\": 10,  \n  \"target_quantum\": [               # Example target: Bell on E0\u2013E1  \n    \"0000\",  # |00>\u2192|00>  \n    \"0110\",  # |01>\u2192|11>  \n    \"1001\",  # |10>\u2192|01>  \n    \"1111\"   # |11>\u2192|10> (CZ\u2010phase embedded in mapping)  \n  ],  \n  \"single_emitters\": [0,1,2],       # E\u2080, E\u2081, E\u2082 inputs  \n  \"removed_connections\": [],        # allow all pair\u2010source paths  \n  \"unicolor\": false,  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}\n\nNode assignment:  \n- single_emitters [0,1,2] are the three matter qubits.  \n- PDC resource sources: S\u2080\u2081, S\u2081\u2082 feed the Bell\u2010measurement circuits.  \n- Gain blocks G\u2080\u2081, G\u2081\u2082 (also PDC sources with tunable pump amplitude) sit inside the two Bell analyzers.  \n- Four ancilla detectors herald which link succeeded.  \n\nBy running Pytheus once to optimize for successful E\u2080\u2013E\u2081 entanglement (target_quanta above, heralding_out on G\u2080\u2081 detectors), then again for E\u2081\u2013E\u2082, one obtains the two routing modes. Our goal is to entangle them by performing entanglement swapping in a coherent superposition of two different swap channels (\u201cupper\u201d and \u201clower\u201d), rather than deciding classically which swap to run. Two extra PDC sources serve as heralded gain blocks that act like quantum switches, controlling which swap arm the ancilla photon travels through\u2014but the choice is kept coherent by a beamsplitter. A final joint detection on the ancilla projects onto the superposed swap order, entangling E\u2080 and E\u2081 in a single experiment.\n\nSetup sketch (top\u2192bottom):\n\n  single_emitters: [E\u2080] \u2014\u2500\u2510                          \u250c\u2500 [E\u2080_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u1d64 \u2500[G\u1d64]\u2500\u2510       \u2502  \nBell-source S\u1d64 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                \u2502       \u251c\u2500 Ancilla detectors (project onto |+\u27e9)  \n                                            \u251c\u2500BS\u2500\u2510  \u2502  \n  single_emitters: [E\u2081] \u2014\u2500\u2510                \u2502    \u2514\u2500\u2524  \u2514\u2500 [E\u2081_out]  \n                           \u251c\u2500 Bell\u2013\ud835\udcd1\u2097 \u2500[G\u2097]\u2500\u2518      BS  \nBell-source S\u2097 \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                      \n\n\u2022 S\u1d64 and S\u2097 are the two PDC pair sources for the upper and lower swap channels.  \n\u2022 G\u1d64 and G\u2097 are additional PDC sources (\u201cgain\u201d blocks) inserted in one ancilla arm of each Bell analyzer (\ud835\udcd1\u1d64,\ud835\udcd1\u2097). Their pump amplitudes set the switching amplitude.  \n\u2022 A 50/50 beamsplitter (BS) coherently mixes the two ancilla modes before detection.  \n\u2022 Four heralding detectors (two on each G-output) post-select the successful \u201csuperposed swap\u201d outcome by detecting the ancilla in the |+\u27e9 basis.  \n\u2022 Conditional on the herald, E\u2080 and E\u2081 emerge entangled\u2014but crucially in a superposition of \u201cswap via upper channel\u201d and \u201cswap via lower channel\u201d\u2014an indefinite-order entanglement swap.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n\n{  \n  \"description\": \"Gain-based quantum SWITCH of two entanglement swaps between two emitter qubits\",  \n  \"foldername\": \"GainSwitchSwap\",  \n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.0,  \n  \"edges_tried\": 30,  \n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\": 4,                # Their pump amplitudes tune the success amplitude (lasing analogue).  \n   \u2022 A linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters mixes the input photons from E\u2081&E\u2082 with their corresponding Bell photons. The two Bell analyzers are each gated by the state of C: when C=|1\u27e9 the teleportation circuits swap, when C=|0\u27e9 they apply identity (by routing the ancilla modes out of the Bell analyzers). \ud835\udcd1-measurement; their pump amplitudes set the effective gain.  \n\u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors on the ancilla arms post-select successful two-hop teleportation.  \n\u2022 By tuning pump strength of G\u2081,G\u2082, the probability that both swaps succeed exhibits a sharp threshold\u2014a lasing-like percolation phase transition in network reachability.  \n\nPytheus config To hit the \u201ctruly new\u201d mark, I need a network\u2010level transformation that hasn\u2019t been in Pytheus\u2019s library\u2014one that blends \u201clasing behavior\u201d (heralded PDC gain) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single_emitters) in a functional primitive, not just a performance tweak.  \n\nA universal 1\u21922 quantum\u2010cloning map on a matter qubit is exactly such a primitive: it\u2019s a non\u2010trivial two\u2010qubit transformation (approximate cloning), it can be cast as a static linear\u2010optical circuit with PDC ancillas and gain blocks (stimulated\u2010emission analogue), and it isn\u2019t mere state generation but implements a mapping of an unknown qubit to two outputs. No one has asked Pytheus to design the Bu\u017eek\u2013Hillery cloning circuit for emitter qubits with heralded PDC gain. This opens an entire family of \u201cgain\u2010boosted\u201d cloning modules and their network concatenations (e.g. cascaded cloners, distributable approximate clones), bridging lasing physics and matter\u2010qubit networks.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a concrete experiment target for Pytheus: a heralded, gain\u2010assisted universal 1\u21922 quantum\u2010cloning module for a single\u2010photon\u2010emitter qubit\u2014merging \u201clasing behavior\u201d (PDC gain) with \u201cstrong light\u2013matter coupling\u201d (single_emitters) in a network transformation.\n\n1) Purpose  \nImplement the Bu\u017eek\u2013Hillery symmetric cloning transformation on an arbitrary input qubit stored in emitter E\u2080, producing two approximate clones on emitter nodes E\u2081 and E\u2082:\n\n|0\u27e9\u2080 \u2192 \u221a(2/3)|0\u27e9\u2081|0\u27e9\u2082 + \u221a(1/6)(|0\u27e9\u2081|1\u27e9\u2082 + |1\u27e9\u2081|0\u27e9\u2082),  \n|1\u27e9\u2080 \u2192 \u221a(2/3)|1\u27e9\u2081|1\u27e9\u2082 + \u221a(1/6)(|0\u27e9\u2081|1\u27e9\u2082 + |1\u27e9\u2081|0\u27e9\u2082).\n\nThis is a genuine two\u2010qubit network transformation, not state generation.\n\n2) Components & Layout  \n\u2022 Single\u2010photon emitter E\u2080 (node 0) holds the unknown input qubit.  \n\u2022 Two additional emitters E\u2081, E\u2082 (nodes 1,2) are initialized in |0\u27e9 states and will carry the clones.  \n\u2022 Two PDC pair\u2010sources S\u2081, S\u2082 supply vacuum\u2010ancilla photons for the cloning network.  \n\u2022 Two heralded PDC \u201cgain\u201d blocks G\u2081, G\u2082 are inserted in the ancilla arms\u2014mimicking stimulated\u2010emission gain that amplifies the |11\u27e9\u2192|11\u27e9 terms.
